description:
This is a little neighborhood old school Chinese on Mission Street with an adjoining bar. Service for phone order and pickup was pleasant and efficient. The food was pretty good though somewhat salty. We got house chow mein, Henry special (chicken/shrimp/scallop in hot bean sauce w/ veg), orange chicken, and a spicy fried dish filet dish which was overpoweringly salty. 

Street parking impossible to find so if you pickup, bring a friend who'll illegally park while you run in.

I would return here because the food was pretty good and prices reasonable, service fast. Sorry no pics though.
author: Trish W.

description:
This place is way better than the other local options.  Dishes are well made and quick to come out.  Servers are very helpful and quite friendly compared to Eric's or Alice's...

Gluten free for most dishes if you want that sort of thing.  It's a bit smaller on the inside but enough seating to accommodate up to groups of six if they aren't too busy.
author: Christopher M.

description:
I very recently started to go to this Noe Valley location after the North Beach restaurant closed temporarily. The food here is amazing, and even better - there is relatively easy-to-find street parking! I think my favorite Henry's dishes are a little bit better at the North Beach location, but it is honestly very hard to tell the difference.

My most recommended dishes are the Ma Po tofu and the Dianna's Special Meat Pie, which both have the excellent Henry's special meat sauce. You can't eat here without getting at least one dish with this savory, spicy meat sauce. It is unlike anything I have ever tasted before. The Smoked Ham and Green Beans are another go-to dish. The meat is very flavorful and the green beans are cooked along with the smoked meat, making them the best tasting vegetable I have ever eaten. The Hot and Sour soup is also great and easy to share with a group of 3-5 people. 

Don't be afraid of ordering too much - the leftovers still taste amazing!
author: Haixing K.

description: Ate here because my friends love it so much. They were pretty tasty. We came in with a group of 7 and no reservations. They accommodates us easily. We all ordered something different. We got the meat pie and dumplings for appetizers. I got the Henry's special, someone else got the fried rice, and someone else got hunan orange sauce chicken. Now this orange chicken was probably one of the best I have had. Lightly breaded and saucy enough without being heavy. So good!!! There was more ordered but I do not remember. It was technically served family style but we ate our own for the most part. If I'm back in San Fran, I would go back.
author: Jacqueline F.

description: Take me to Church. "Henry's Hunan Restaurant" has been a balls out, spice-heaven family chain for decades. It's so highly regarded in the extraordinary that this Bay Area treasure has been highlighted as a New Yorker magazine favorite, and as long as the menu never changes its reputation will never cease as a community foodie tabernacle. What should you order? Well, the idea is to come with at least four family members and then order about six dishes (take the rest home, who gets the rest is a problem for later), and if you love smoked ham go Marty's Special, if you love spicy chicken and shrimp go Henry's Special, and if you love chow mein -- you better love chow mein, it's never better anywhere else! There are multiple locations, but this gleamy white and fresh and clean spot is found on 1708 Church St, San Francisco, CA 94131. #classiceats
author: Sean C.

description: First thing you need to know: the dumplings are awesome. Every other dish was ruined with way too much salt. We shared Mongolian Beef, spicy chicken and Henry's Special. All close to inedible from the salt. Service was a bit spotty too. Had to get our own water refills a few times.
author: Michael N.

description:
Oh my goodness! I feel SO much better now. A big bowl of Hot and Sour Soup, Smoked Ham entree (the best!), dry fried green beens. So delicious! We started it all off with an order of dumplings. The sauce makes them even more than perfect!

I had to come HERE to get over my over-the-top-disappointing recent experience at their Bryant Street location. They seem completely unrelated anymore. 

I love over-ordering here so I can take some home for the next couple of days. Take a Dianna's Meat Pie home for tonight! Delicious hot or cold!

When I first came to SF 38 years ago, I found Henry's Hunan in a San Francisco guidebook and their original Kearny St. location, then Sansome St. location, quickly become my #1 favorite go-to place for a great lunch! Dinner is good too, but sometimes I find myself overindulging, so I prefer lunch here. The food is the same. I am soooooo glad they opened a location out on Church Street.

Try the Hunan Ribs, too, they come with a black bean sauce that is rich and delicious. Marty's Special, Garlic Chicken, Shrimp and Green Beans... all so very satisfying. And the food comes piping hot, bright with flavors and shining colors that are a feast for eyes. 

Darn it! Now that I've written this I need to get up and go back there!
Save me a window table!
author: James G.

description:
Absolutely great! The Diana's special meat pie is like nothing I've ever had before: a crisp pancake sandwich giving way to the most savory of meat sauces, with iceberg lettuce for a bit of freshness. The smoked ham with string beans is packed with flavor, and the ma po tofu is probably the best in the Bay Area. The Henry's special was pretty tasty as well. I wish I could try more dishes, but it is too difficult to resist ordering all the known delights first....

Go here! Their North Beach location is also just as good, but I've had lesser experiences at their locations nearer Chinatown/Financial District.
author: Thomas S.

description: The only good remaining Hunan around in SF. I've been going to the one on Sansome street for years as a kid until it closed a few years ago. But unlike a certain location south of market, this location seems to replicate all the classic cooking methods to perfection. Has easy parking which is already a plus and wait staff is very friendly and provide good hospitality. They're never packed and are able to seat guests without hassle. Whenever I'm able to visit sf I'll always recommend this place as a good fresh Chinese restaurant.
author: Aaron C.

description: Looking for a Chinese food fix and was terribly disappointed. Ordered orange sauce chicken and shrimp chow mein...meh. Totally bland!
author: Sara S.

description: Friendly staff, good food. I ordered to go and got my food in a good amount of time. I will be back to try more dishes from the vegetarian section of the menu.
author: Heather M.

description:
These guys know how to cook delicious food for affordable price and how to provide outstanding service.

I've tried dumplings from may places but Henry's dumplings were so far the best. Harmony between taste, texture and quality. Also I suggest you to get Mongolian beef, absolutely delicious.

The atmosphere was quite and relaxing, the only aspect I didn't like so much is that this place is a little small.
author: Mark K.

description: This location on Church Street used to be one of my favorite Chinese restaurants in the city. Unfortunately, this place has lost its touch. I'm not sure what's happened. They changed managers or something about six months ago and ever since the food, and the service has been subpar. There used to be a bright, on the ball woman who was the manager and she did a fabulous job. When she left, the place changed and I haven't enjoyed my visits. Today, I took a few bites of my egg rolls and a few of my spicy curry chow mein and then left. It didn't taste good I'm sorry to say.
author: Chris L.

description: We have come here multiple times and it's sort of hit or miss. We came last night for dinner and it was a big miss. Both me and my boyfriend got food poisoning from the food. Not happy about it.
author: Annalisa H.

description: If you love spicy food, this place is for you! First time customer and I came here yesterday for lunch yesterday. I ordered the beef chow mein and it was pretty spicy compared to other places I've tried. I personally love spicy food so I was super happy with my order. I also ordered the vegetarian egg rolls and they were cooked to perfection. Waitress was friendly and I love that this place is so close to my workplace. I'll be stopping by for lunch again sometime!
author: Jasmine V.

description: Honestly, this is some of the best Chinese food that I've had since coming to the city and it's right next door. I moved from the San Gabriel Valley in LA so I grew up eating dim sum and Cantonese style BBQ. Everything was awesome. We ordered the spring rolls, hot and sour soup, garlic chicken, and curry chow mein with beef. The steak wasn't the best quality but, man, were those noodles absolutely delicious (and maybe a bit salty). It's everything you need from Chinese food - uncompromisingly authentic, delicious, and affordable. I'll be back for more.
author: Travis V.

description:
Get Diana's Pie appetizer. That's all you really need to know.

Fine, you should also know: BBQ pork dishes are the best dishes here.
author: Peter K.

description:
Henry's Hunan is still amazing after decades!  

Go to dishes:

*Meat pie
*Marty's Special
*Henry's Special
*Harvest Pork
*Sweet and Sour Rock Cod
*String Beans with Shrimp

Enjoy!

G
author: Gino R.

description: It's a decent Chinese spot. Very inexpensive, fresh and tasty but very greasy. Definitely a must try place. I really like their dumplings and Mongolian beef.
author: Sumbal A.

description:
A dinner disaster. This is the worst Chinese food I have EVER EVER EVER experienced, and the worst overall restaurant experience I have EVER had. 

The service was bad. Had to get our own menu's off of the counter. "Waitress" / "manager" / "owner" lady  had the look of "I have better things to do", like jotting down the phoned in delivery orders.  Had to get up with a water glass and ask for more water. 

o  Chow Mein - seemed like the over-sized mushy noodles were fried in abundant RANCID oil (greasy)

o  Garlic Chicken - overcome by an abundant supply of under cooked carrot slices, and skimpy chicken pieces, a SMALL wisper of garlic

o  Egg plant salad  - ODD, slices of overcooked egg plant drowned in a soy sauce/sesame oil bath

After a taste of each, I could not eat these dishes. My honey had the same reaction. He nor I are super picky eaters. As we get ready to leave a new "waiter" appears who looks like he had just been washing dishes, and asks if we would like to take home the "leftovers".  99% of what they served remained on the plates.  We decline. He looks puzzled, and turns around and walks away, w/o removing the bad food from the table. NO inquiry as to why we didn't eat what we ordered and are paying for. 

With an over-all rating of FOUR STARS, we were drawn in.  The food and service will keep us out. I know that some of the other Henry's Hunan chain locations (SOMA etc.), have lines out the door and rave reviews. Good for them. This experience was REALLY BAD for me.
author: Matsuo U.

description: Their spicy curry vegetarian noodles are the best. I also like the hot & sour veggies & their house tofu. Very different flavors compared to other Chinese food, much more peppery, spicy & sour. Very flavorful and great when I'm in the mood for a change from the norm.
author: Marybeth S.

description:
The staff is very nice here and the food is OK. We brought and old friend for lunch and he ordered the smoked ham chow menu. On first bite it tasted good but after that I didn't care much for it. Hubby got Diane's meat pie to try. I'd skip it and would rather just have the onion pancakes.  This consisted of meat sandwiched between 2 onion pancakes. Reminded me of Taco Bell's Mexican pizza.  

I ordered the spare rib and a bowl of white rice. The bowl of rice fed 3. The ribs were stir fried in a brown sauce. It was too salty. Their food could be less heavy handed on the salt or soy.  I've tried Henry's in North Beach and thought the food there was better.
author: Ry T.

description: One of the best Chinese food places in SF, with genuinely caring owners and support staff. Try the Hot and Sour soup
author: K P.

description: Extremely good food. Very fresh ingredients and very warm service. We go here weekly and have never been disappointed.
author: Michael M.

description: If you order online, you're order will be sent to the one on Mission Street.  Super annoying.
author: Bob W.

description: Ordered take out ( small hot and sour soup, chicken with string beans and mapo tofu) from here a couple nights ago. Pick up was quick, and the food was hot. They turned the small soup I ordered into a large and charged me extra for it . I wish I had noticed before I got home. The mapo tofu and soup we're both incredibly vinegary and sour. The mapo really lacked any other flavor. The chicken and string beans were good, the beans were still crispy but where's the chicken?? Both the chicken and mapo tofu we're seriously lacking in meat. The chicken to bean ratio was way off. I think I'll stick to Alice's when I crave Chinese take out.
author: Trena M.

description:
This place is down the street from me and convenient so I'm a frequent take-out customer. A reason why I love this place is because they use no MSG. Woohoo! 

I always order the same things: Vegetable fried rice, beef chow-fun, and hot/sour soup. Can't say it's the best I've ever had on all 3 fronts but if you live in the hood, it's the best you're going to get. I like this place better than Alice's and Eric's. Plus, they deliver!
author: Emily Y.

description:
I order a dish that's not on the menu every time I eat here. It's called Hunan Xiao Chao Rou 湖南小炒肉, thinly sliced small pieces of pork belly。I ordered this yesterday, and the meat were MUCH MORE fatty than the usual amount, it was cut not thin like the usual. Also, it was not cooked long enough for the thickness of the cut, so the fatty part is disgusting to eat! If you have lowered your standard in your food, I will not eat here anymore. 

我每个月都吃你们的湖南小炒肉，昨晚上的肉切的也太厚了，肥的部分也太多了，这种肉便宜的不行，你们这么做太对不起老顾客了。昨天晚上太失望了。
author: Bubble T.

description:
Truly not impressed with this place. The check-in girl I thought at first was dressed up for Halloween but it was her normal clothing. She looked like something from a dominatrix movie. Her attitude wasn't the best or the friendliest either when we arrived at the restaurant. She tossed the menu on the table. We ordered the Kong pao chicken but it was mostly black beans and he was extremely salty. Though we also ordered Mongolian beef and it was tasty mostly onions than beef. The price was decent and the service was good. Will we come back? With other Chinese restaurant in town, I highly doubt it.

Price: OK
Service: good
Quality: decent
Cleanliness call him OK (we arrived just as they open the restaurant so there was no room for messiness in the restaurant)

Note: interestingly enough, when we were going to pay for our bill, we had to pay at a window like at a public clinic.
author: Apit L.

description:
The day before my surgery and I was craving Asian noodles. 

We grabbed an early dinner on a Sunday evening at around 5:30PM and were quickly seated with plenty of room to spare. Sadly, however, they didn't have chow fun noodles!

Here's what we ordered:

Dumpling appetizer - Pretty good, serviced spicy

Onion cake - Fluffy, less onion than I expected, more just like eating dough

Chicken chow fun - A bit greasy for my taste, and overly salty

Sautéed Deluxe Vegetables - Ok, but also a bit salty

Henry's Special - Pretty good, shrimp was tasty, but I'm not a fan of the scallops. Also salty.

Overall, I really wanted to like this place and it was my first time trying a Henry Hunan, but I left disappointed.
author: Leana L.

description:
Bought some take out on a whim and they didn't disappoint:  the Hot & Sour Beef remains a classic-- I have ordered it almost every time I go to any of the Henry's locations and it was as delicious as ever.  Instead of getting one of the pork dishes (some of my favorites) I ordered the Black Bean Sauce Chicken.  It was a little on the sweet side for my taste (took off a star).  However, the cabbage and other vegetables it came with were very tasty.  

I love Henry's and this first visit to this location confirmed they have it going on whichever location you choose.
author: Howard D.

description:
Ordered from here on Door Dash. Had high hopes.

Man, were they squashed. 

The green beans were the best they had to offer. Spicy, but wayyyy greasy.

The Kung Pao chicken was stingy on the peanuts and veggies, and hella greasy. Missing so much flavor.

Wouldn't order from here again, whatta shame, but mama gotta watch her lipid panel.
author: Gabriela W.

description:
Good food but pretty good spice on most of them. Their food tastes quite fresh and I've been a huge fan. Been going here for a while now and it's always consistent. 

I recommend this place to anyone that likes spicy food.
author: Rohan D.

description:
Love this place:

* The staff is amazing and treats you like family.
* The food is great.
* They don't add a ton of corn starch and other crap that leaves you feeling sick afterwards.
* I order the chicken and string beans once a week.
* The Mongolian beef is a favorite as well. 
* Never ordered something from here that I didn't like.
author: Aaron V.

description:
Tried to go to Regent Thai on a rainy day, but they were closed so we came over here instead for lunch.

We ordered the hot and sour soup, and I got the Mongolian beef with rice. The soup came out steaming hot and I loved it. The Mongolian Beef was also very tasty and flavorful and I really enjoyed it as well. It went very well with the rice.

I would come back here again.
author: Jessica S.

description: Food is solid but the thing that earns them 5 stars from me is the crazy fast and reliable delivery. I've ordered from them 3 times now and each time they have delivered within their quoted window (45min) and were polite and shockingly patient over the phone. I also appreciate that the food is msg free.
author: Jean L.

description: Our go-to Chinese takeout spot in the neighborhood (although the inside looks nice too). Friendly staff and the food is just multiple cuts above the other nearby Chinese spots. Great Ma-po tofu and dumplings. I also am a big fan of their orange chicken, my guilty pleasure.
author: Sean M.

description:
I really enjoy eating here, the food is always so fresh and delicious!!!

I wouldn't be afraid to order something "extra spicy" because "spicy" does nothing for me.  But then again I literally douse everything in Sriracha and red chili flakes sooooo keep that in mind. 

They also give you a fortune cookie from a giant jar! How fun!  Way cuter than getting it on your check.  (It's those hidden nuggets of delight that count people!)

I've ordered a bunch of different things from here and have yet to be disappointed.  

Although the pancakes were not what I was expecting, much thinner than the Korean ones I am accustomed to, probably would't get those again. 

But I highly recommend this place!  Fresh.  Spicy.  Chinese food.
author: Christina L.

description:
Its right by my place and love it. The curry chow mein is awesome good. Its a very mom & pop place. I guess the chef owns the place & is willing to customize. 
Totally recommend
author: Shahul H.

description:
Truly an amazing and above standard Chinese restaurant. Great food at amazing prices. For those that are new to Henry Hunan, its a chain established and run by a family in San Francisco, and I can honestly say that the one located on Church St is the only one that I love to frequent. Jeff who is the owner of the Henry Hunan on Church st. is a great man and has always been a great individual to sit down and have great conversations with. I even invited him and his family to my son's 1st birthday, which he attended and even brought my son a little gift. 

Aside from the close relationship that I have with Jeff, his restaurant and his standards of cooking and running a business are out of this world. The man goes above and beyond to please his clientele and make sure that everyone is happy during and after their meal. The man deserves an immense amount of recognition for not only the service he provides, but the quality of food that he strives to provide his patrons. 

The food is out of this world and I always order Henry's special and fried rice along with some good ol' pot stickers and baby bok choy with chicken or green beans. Let's not leave out the hot and sour soup with tofu. 

Great place to visit and dont be hesitant to order any dish on the menu, even if you are not familiar with hunan cuisine (xiang cuisine). 

Jeff my man, you deserve a Michelin star in my book!
author: Jose B.

description: Trekked to the Noe Valley location of Henry's Hunan to honor the passing of founder Henry Chung at age 99 (you can read his fascinating life story on SFGate).  The owners (?) Mary and Ivan were wonderfully kind and hospitable to us.  The restaurant is bright, clean, and modern ~ a very nice ambiance, as other reviewers have mentioned.  It was a warm afternoon, and made for a very pleasant lunch with the front windows of the restaurant wide open.  The food was high quality and delicious, and very inexpensive!  The menu featured some interesting dishes (onion cakes, cold bean curd salad, 8-Vegetable Delight) that I have not seen at other Chinese restaurants.  Fun to eat at a restaurant that is a part of SF history.
author: Matt and Rita C.

description: went here for a office party. We shared 10 diffrent dishes the boss ordered as she had been their before. Every dish was great! really liked the chicken chow mein.
author: Michael W.

description: Solid Chinese fare, though far from the best. Dig the smoky and sour flavors. Decent level of spice but not as much as I'm used to in Hunan cooking.
author: Aaron A.

description: I am dismayed at all the good reviews of this restaurant as our dinner was not very good. We ordered the won ton soup which tasted bland and needed lots of soy sauce. There was literally nothing in the soup except stock and some won tons. No vegetables, pork, shrimp or anything else. We ordered the pork fried rice with egg. It looked like white rice with a few pieces of pork and some dry egg. Again we had to add soy sauce. Main dishes were way too greasy/oily. My beef with green onions had as much sliced yellow onions as beef so it filled out the plate but was way too much yellow onion. I guess they did this to save on the beef. Other dishes were also too oily and lacked any real depth of flavors. I am again surprised that this restaurant received good reviews. In a city that has so many amazing Chinese restaurants, I would definitely not return.
author: Ron S.

description: Wow. So good. We had garlic chicken and  the house bean curd. Both really good, smokey, nice flavor. Def would revisit!
author: T A.

description:
I ordered pot stickers and chicken chow mein. To go. The potstickers were so dry inside there was not enough moisture in the meat to chew it without feeling like I was chewing a small super ball. Also it lacked flavor and spice -They pour the pot sticker sauce in the container which spilled all over the bag -The chicken chow mein was very bland almost all noodle and Definitely not worth the $$! What a disappointment
I have to say this was the worst place I have ever been to for Chinese food and I go a lot. Sorry but I have to be honest here - positive points - the people seemed friendly and they used cardboard not styrofoam for their to go orders
author: Eve D.

description:
I'm only human.

This is where I looked at the slip of paper Miss Yoga gave me.

I was wondering why she handed me a piece of folded paper before she left. Turns out it was her phone number and e-mail.

I think she's as spicy as the food they serve here.

My buddy Chris introduced me to this place because of their dumplings. I told him that China's dumplings were much better, but what does he know?

This place serves big portions and caters to the locals like my buddy who gets priority seating when he walks through the door.

The eggplant I had was spicy, and honestly, I'm not a fan of their food, but if I wanted average spicy Mandarian food, I guess this place would appeal to me.

So my friend laughs at me and tells me to call Miss Yoga, who as her name suggests, is a Yoga instructor.

3 weeks later I called her for a date.
author: Jack R.

description: Convenient location. Love their basics: chow mein and fried rice. Their shrimp and green bean dish is pretty good as well. Please note that they do not deliver on Tuesdays.
author: Mel P.

description:
This is my Friday night go to place with my partner.

Since it has opened, we arrive randomly and always sit at the counter, without asking, tea, water and a beer for me arrive, with an automatic order for dumplings (which are amazing and hand made), spicy chili sauce, made for me by hand and soy and black bean sauce for my partner....

I can not say enough about this place!  It's like a second home with a lovely caring family...

Most orders are to go and they do deliver if you are close...( I watch all the app deliver drivers walk in. point the phone rudely at a kind staff and pick up the order. If there is a review here from an app person, for delivery, please ignore it, and please ignore the drivers that are picking it up, from first hand experience, they double park and are rude..)

Highlights are kung pao, spicy cod, DUMPLINGS and the meat pie, which can be ordered in a half portion, (not recommended to go, as i can get soggy, yet it is incredibly delicious!)

another fantastic place in noe valley, and such great people and amazing food.

KISSES to MARY
author: Phil A.

description: Good food. I like the beef broccoli and the rice but and the sweet and sour chicken. Just not a good idea to leave the sweet and sour chicken in the fridge and eat it the next day for leftovers since it's not as fresh also they could perhaps not use as much sauce but w/e all Chinese food is like this so not much of a difference from other places I guess.
author: John T.

description: Consistent word coming out of my boyfriend's mouth...salty.  Unfortunately it was too salty for him.  We told the waiter and their customer service was great.  They cooked the dish again and made it less salty so he was able to digest his meal.  The restaurant wasn't his fave but the rest of the family were okay with it, I was too.  I liked their noodles with shrimp.  My sister enjoyed their eggplant with minced pork.  My nephew gobbled his Kung pao chicken like he hadn't eaten in weeks.  My mom sided with my boyfriend but she did eat a lot of the dishes without complaint.  My nephews loved the combo noodles.  Their rock cod fish was a little hard.  Okay, to be fair, some pieces of fish were soft and others were a little chewy.  Overall good restaurant.  It was hot in the restaurant.  I was sweating while eating but to be fair, SF was having a heat wave.  Just wish i wasn't sweating so much.
author: Nerinna V.

description:
Not sure if I get all the rage with this place.
While food is hot and spicy, they really cater to a non authentic Chinese community.

In fact I asked what's there for a Chinese guy who wants the real stuff.  Their answer was honest, we don't cater to real Chinese taste.

Food is ok, ingredient is not of quality as prawn is small.  Rather prefer millbrae or Fremont real stuff.

Brown rice for example caters to a non asian community, yet I do like steamed brown rice.

Just don't expect real Chinese veggies like on choy, a choy, or anything
author: David H.

description:
I just ordered the string beans with shrimp for delivery and it was amazing!! 
First of all I asked for delivery across the street cause I couldn't leave the house. Then I ordered only this one dish AND had to pay with credit card.
They were just great. I waited maybe 15 minutes, had the nicest service ever and delicious food!
author: Caroline K.

description:
If I had to be perfectly honest, I would say from all the Chinese restaurants I have dined at, this was one of the least authentically prepared. The house special garlic chicken, had little flavor or garlic taste to it at all and rather than adding a variety of veggies such as zucchini (having had this dish at other places.) The Mongolian beef that several people mentioned was the best they ever had, probably never ate it at an authentic Chinese restaurant were diners were mostly Chinese, as the sauce was in no way resembled this classic dish, which was heavily sprinkled with pepper flakes (but still had no heat to it) instead of using actual chili peppers and did not use the cellophane crispy noodles either. 

As mentioned in a few reviews, some dishes tasted a bit over salted. As far as service goes, our waiter was friendly and helpful in deciding what to get, I only wish the food was as good as the service. If you want something quick or need delivery, I'm sure Henry's would still be a decent choice.
author: Petra S.

description: Oh so good!  We came here with a big group so we got to try a bit of everything- favorites we're the green beans with meat sauce, Marty's special (smoked ham with vegetables), Kung pao chicken, dumplings, and the meat pie (I know it sounds odd, but it is a must try, so delicious).  Everything was very fresh, spice level was perfect on the spicy items. This is absolutely the best Chinese around.
author: Rachel M.

description: The place is basically half bar/restaurant. The food wasn't that great. And while sitting on the restaurant side of the place the bar side is kinda loud. I wouldn't go back.
author: Sareen K.

description: This is how Chinese food is suppose to taste! I use to deliver meat & poultry with my father to their older locations when I was younger. I felt like a kid again once when I had taken my first bite of the chicken chow mein. We also had the sweet & sour chicken, shrimp fried rice, onion cakes and the beef with string beans. The staff was super friendly and most importantly the food was tasty and fresh
author: Raymond L.

description:
Just Chinese food.

I'm not saying is not good. The ambiance though is a little nicer than any other Chinese restaurant. It looks clean, and even they had many orders (mostly phone orders), the food came out fast.

The service is for sure not great. Price is fine, we only spent $15 for one main course and rice for two.

I didn't order any of the specials Yelpers recommend, so maybe it's my fault for following my heart rather than Yelp.
author: Maggie J.

description: Best Potstickers we've EVER had!  Went on a whim and now we're SOLD
author: Ingrid A.

description:
one of the dishes we ordered, the spicy cod, which is battered and deep fried, had a somewhat stale/plastic-y feel when I bit into it. as if they fried it yesterday, then stored it overnight in the fridge, then reheated it before serving. i wanted to ask them that, but i forgot. flavor was good though. 

the other dish we ordered, the orange chicken, had a lot of batter not a lot of meat in the platter. taste.. it was standard.
author: mark s.

description:
This place is lost in a mirage of 5 stars. basically the food is overall extremely salty and marginal quality. My Filipino girlfriend (pork expert) and I ate here today and was the only people there except when an older Chinese group came in. We had to beg for service then. When we told him the "Harvest Pork" was not good at all, he refused to taste it and denied the pork being bad. Meanwhile my girlfriend was puking in the restaurant bathroom. He said we should have told them sooner!!! Thanks for being a racist and generally mean host, you ass! Instead of taking the pork off the bill, you now have a horrible review and lost two customers, bravo!

I actually went back to the restaurant just now and told everyone don't get the Harvest Pork. Thanks JEFF!!!
author: Silicon W.

description:
This is a weekend staple for my friend group. They know us and the dishes we like which is awesome.

Highly recommend the dumplings, house bean curd, Kung pao chicken, and eggplant.  But really everything is good. 

Just wrapped up a dinner here for less than $12/person, including tip. You can't beat that in Noe Valley!
author: Natalie S.

description: The worse place for service ever. No one can understand anything your saying. It's terrible.
author: John Michael N.

description: I would give this place 0 stars if I could. My husband and I tried this place out. We traveled from San Leandro to here to try the food. We were really disappointed with the service. When we got there not many tables to chose from, not because it was busy, but because tables were dirty. We finally got seated and decided what to eat. We ordered meat pie, prawn chow mein, beef Kung pao, orange chicken, and sautéed scallops. The meat pie was the best out of all 5 dishes and it wasn't even all that good. The chow mein taster burnt, the side dishes were super greasy/oily and salted. We didn't finish all of our food. Most of the main meat dishes had way too much chopped onions. We left and about 40min after eating we were stuck in traffic and my stomach wasn't feeling the food. My husband literally had to get off in emeryville so I can use the bathroom at Starbucks. I almost didn't make it. We then got home and I continued going to the bathroom. Two hours later and my husband started to feel sick too. We ended up having to fight for the bathroom. NEVER going here again! Wouldn't recommend this place even to the person I don't like. It was a horrible after experience. Ruined my day.
author: Priscila V.

description: Had a great lunch here yesterday. We were heading home from the park and had our baby and dog with us. Luckily, this place has a table outside and a high-chair. Staff was friendly and attentive. Food was good and prices were reasonable. Definitely worth a visit for lunch.
author: Josh M.

description:
You can probably find other better Hunan restaurants in SF. This restaurant was unfortunately not as great as we've heard/read.

We shared:
1) the dumplings -- an appetizer comes with 6 in a small pool of spicy, salty, sesame-oil tasting sauce. If you want extra chili oil on the side, they will gladly provide some. I liked these dumplings...if I am to come back to this restaurant, it would probably be for the dumplings only. They were of good size, had good texture, and were yummy.
2) Henry's Special: shrimp, scallops, chicken, & veggies with some overly salty sauce. The pieces of scallop, shrimp, and chicken were tender and moist, but it would have been nice to see more than a couple of pieces here and there. We ordered this dish with the brown rice.

I was really disappointed with Henry's Special. The sauce that comes on it is SO SALTY and other than the salt, there is no other depth of flavor. I was going to give 2 stars for the food, but I added an extra star for the courteous and attentive service.

Had high expectations for this place, but left disappointed. I may come back for the dumplings though if the craving arises.
author: Maki K.

description:
The hot and sour soup is the best in the bay area hands down and you'll find dishes like the meat pie you won't find elsewhere.  Tofu is always perfect, great dumplings.  Spicy black bean sauce on any dish is great, and they have their own chili paste on the table if you need more spice in your life.  

Love the people that complain about Henry's not being authentic and then complain about the service or the prawns.  Wait... what??  The service can be slow but that's because they are busy.  Just like any decent place in Asia or New York and London.  Never had Henry's flavor elsewhere and have tried many here and abroad.  Henry's is Henry's and it's damn good.
author: Tobin J.

description:
Jeff is one of the friendliest people I have ever met and it was my first time meeting him.  Granted I was in good company but he bought me a free beer.  I can't complain there - I was off to a great start.

The food here is SO flavorful and they don't use MSG so you know you're getting quality you can taste.  I have never had such fresh Chinese food before and I'm a big fan of Chinese.  This is the only Chinese restaurant that I know of that has a Michelin star.
author: Kevin J.

description: The happiest people you'll ever meet. Everyone is smiling and enjoying this amazing and fresh food. Great neighborhood eatery, I shall return.
author: Ms. V O.

description: Had dinner at Henrys and was very disappointed, especially given the yelp rating.  We ordered the kung pao shrimp and the garlic chicken.  Both were bland and flavorless.  They were also drenched in sauce.  The shrimp itself was slightly undercooked and had a fishy smell.  Would not come back here.
author: Amit P.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVEEEEEEE THIS PLACE!

I've been coming here for years now and have NEVER been disappointed so i figured it was time for a review!

First of all, the hot and sour soup is the best hot and sour soup I have ever had IN MY LIFE (and i'm pretty hard to please), I can't just eat one small bowl that they give you at dinner so I get a WHOLE order of it and STILL eat it all!

The perfect meal for me at Henry's is the vegetable fried rice, the orange chicken (order it spicy), and the broccoli beef. It's super hard to find the PERFECT orange chicken, either it's too orang-ey, or not enough, or the chicken is too big or too small, Henry's Hunan orange chicken is JUST RIGHT! The flavor is kickin but not overpowering, the spice is just right and the chicken pieces are the perfect size and have the most perfect crunch to them! LOVE IT! everything also tastes so fresh, you can tell they don't freeze anything. 

Love the service and how they give you hot tea without having to ask for it! Parking is meeehhh and this neighborhood is a little too snooty for me, the only reason why I go into this neighborhood is for Henry's so, GOOD JOB HENRY'S!!! Love you guys xoxoxoxo.
author: Courtney S.

description: Hot sour beef is sooo good!
author: Carla F.

description:
3.5 stars 

We shared: 
-- dumplings: Enjoyed the pool of spicy sauce, but wish their dumplings were more like a real dumpling, & less like a pork potsticker *confused face*
-- wonton soup: broth was light in body & flavor, which I liked. Wontons were pretty good until I bit into something hard...twice...(cartilage? Ick.) 
-- beef fried rice: bf liked the generous pieces of thin, lean beef. Rice needed a bit more soy sauce. Not a contender for his favorite fried rice. 
-- henry's special: shrimp, scallops, & chicken: reminded me of the ingredients that make up a kung pow dish. I think I found one scallop & a few chopped pieces of shrimp, but was to be expected, given the inexpensive price (~$8-$9.) 

Took them a few minutes to notice us & seat us on this unbusy weeknight. Not something I'd usually pick on, but contributed to the lack of warmth & attention I was getting from their staff. 

Still on the hunt for a Chinese food joint I can call my own.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
San Francisco is the location for review number 200, Henry's Hunan is a fitting way to reach that milestone.

Previously I had always neglected Henry's Hunan in my rush to get to Regent Thai on the same block, but in the mood for something different and at the suggestion of Julia D's parents we headed to Henry's Hunan. 

We ordered a decent selection from the menu, I ordered the garlic chicken but I also sampled beef with brocoli and chow mein from the other plates on the table. All of the food was great and I would definitely return. Asian food is so much better in San Francisco than the London fare I am used to.
author: Matt B.

description: Good overall, yummy dumplings and meat pie. Excellent hot curry chow mein. My lunch partners had tofu with veggies and beef and broccoli, which they both liked. Might go again, but we have an ocean of these, except for Hunan, their specialty.
author: Albert K.

description: We ordered the dried sauteed green beans which were not dried, and the Cod Fillets were almost spoiled. Also, their prices are not on the website, and I was not told what the price would be until I picked the order up.
author: Steve C.

description: My true loyal hunan fave. Love this place hard. Always excellent service (hey Jeff!) and hearty delicious dishes (my personal addiction is the mongolian chicken extra dry sauté with a side order of brown rice...hits the spot every time dammit). Just can't stay away ;p
author: Carmel D.

description:
I order from Henry Hunan all the time, since they are a block from my house.  They have great Chinese, and are super friendly.  You won't be disappointed.  
Try Henry's Special and the onion pancakes.  The Mongolian Beef is great too.
author: Tom W.

description: First time I've ever eaten Chinese food and not felt like I was about to explode. I got the wonton soup, chicken fried rice and eight vegetable delight, split it with two friends. The rice was so fluffy and flavorful. The vegetables were in this amazing bean sauce and the wonton soup had such generous portioned wontons and really tasted like it was made with love. The vegetables were cooked the perfect amount, what I would describe as vegetable al dente, still had that crunch.
author: Sheva T.

description: Excellent food and service. I wish we had one in the Richmond District or Pacific Heights area.
author: Emilia G.

description: LOVE. Light, tasty. Finally found the Chinese restaurant everyone has been talking about! Best in Noe. Go!
author: jen m.

description: Love Henry's. Been ordering delivery and eating there for the last five years and it's SOLID good food and nice staff. All the dishes are great and they're especially patient with families and food-flinging toddlers. Delivery takes a while, but it's worth it. Thanks Henry Hunan!
author: Ms X.

description:
Ordered delivery for the first time. First, very impressed by the prompt and courteous service over the phone. 

The delivery: Very impressed by the delivery service. The food arrived earlier than expected (what a nice surprise); however, I ran out for an errand. The delivery person dutiful waited until I returned home. Above and beyond! 

The food: We ordered the chicken salad, sour and spicy chicken, and string beans. All were superb. The chicken salad was very unique and tasty. The sour and spicy chicken tasked like a stir-friend version of hot and sour soup. I loved it, but make sure you like "sour" dishes. The green beans were super fresh and tasty!
author: Matthew B.

description:
We really liked this place and highly recommend it to you.  Delicious food, clean establishment and good service.  We never had to wait too long for a dish and our glasses weren't empty for long.  We saw nine different customers roll up, double-park and then dash through the rain to collect their precious takeout.

Here's what we devoured and what we thought about it:

1. Onion cake: this was okay, not awesome.  We liked the pre-packaged ones sold at 99 Ranch Market better, you know... the toaster-oven ones. *^_^*
2. Dumplings, veggie: wish we had ordered another serving of these.  These dumplings went well with a cup of freshly food-processored, housemade hot chilis and garlic (hot sauce?).  It's definitely that the housemade hot sauce made these dumplings better.  Ask for this and put a small amount on each bite. 
3. Hot & sour soup: wouldn't order again, not complex enough for me.
4. Henry's special (stir-fried chicken, scallops, vegetables): didn't eat this stir-fry, but the other two ate all of it between them.  It's a mixed dish with chicken and seafood, a crowd-pleaser.
5. Fried rice with shrimp: excellent.  Fluffy and full of goodies.  Satisfying without being oily.
6. Bok choy with tofu: fresh-tasting, crunchy and light, not your average overcooked bok choy with sickeningly thick sauce.

One more thing - this place is right off the J, so really, you've no excuse.  You don't even need to double-park.  Eat here!
author: Coleen C.

description: This hole in the wall restaurant is delicious! The restaurant is super clean and the food is freshly made. Staff is friendly and quick. Some outdoor seating is available. Street parking was a challenge (typical for SF). I recommend the vegetable mu shu, shrimp with Napa cabbage, and the onion cakes- yummy! I will definitely be going back here to try other dishes.
author: Erika B.

description:
The best Chinese food in the city!

Invariably fresh, and with no MSG-  you can tell by the way the food tastes and how it makes you feel after...even if you eat a huge meal, like I choose to do every time. 

The ambiance is modern, while maintaining a intimate feel. You can tell the recipes have been passed down for years.

The orange chicken and Mongolian beef are two favorites. The vegetable fried rice is super tasty and is always filled with brightly colored vegetables. 

Henry's is  consistently delicious!
author: Nika C.

description: Oh dear what happened ? I always loved this place but it was a while since I've been here I ordered sweet and sour pork but it was bland and the pork fatty I only ate a few spoonfuls and couldn't eat anymore I heard that Jeff who was always so wonderful wasn't there anymore. I did call to mention it and the person did offer a credit for my next meal but I dont know if I will go again
author: lyn m.

description: Really nice folks at this location. I ordered take out and they offered me a seat at the bar as well as hot tea while I waited for my food. Wide selection of items, lots of spicy items, great fresh vegetable options. Would definitely come back here either sit down or take out if we are in the area.
author: Betty C.

description: Pretty tasty Chinese joint. The dishes are a bit more of the American Chinese version. If you go a little farther into Chinatown you can find some more of authentic Chinese places. We were not brave enough to give them a try.
author: Ben B.

description:
We've been coming here religiously for the past year. The food is fresh and very tasty, the prices are fair, and the service is extremely friendly. We are always met with a smile here!

A unique highlight would have to be Diana's Meat Pie. This is a delicious appetizer that is very large and ideal to share with 2-4 total people. It's two circular fried pieces of Chinese pancake with Parmesan, ground beef, and cabbage inside. You must try it!
author: Brian J.

description: I've been going to one Henry's location or another ever since the New Yorker called this SF gem the best Chinese food in the world, 40+ years now. Still addicted to their smoked ham, hot. The folks who run this location are the best. Sweet, friendly and they put together an amazingly flavorful menu. Their chili, oil and black bean hot sauce is incredible. Love the texture and flavor of their onion cakes, Henry's special, wow. If you like your Chinese food with a little kick and packed with taste, you will love Henry's. Keep up the good work, and please open a location closer to home, down on the peninsula.
author: Ric S.

description:
This is my favorite Hunan restaurant in the US. If you order broccoli beef, orange chicken, or egg rolls, then, this is average "Chinese" food. Henry's restaurant expertly creates smoked meats. This is a Hunan specialty. The squid in black bean sauce is lovely. Marty's special has huge scallops and chicken in it. When I could eat wheat, the cold chicken salad was one of my favorites. 

One thing that you must bear in mind when you judge food is not only are some tastes acquired, but textures are too. (I'm rebutting the arguments of my friends.) The ma po tofu has extra soft tofu combined with a spicy meat sauce. The country vegetable are one of my favorites, but another person might think the dish to be oily. Actually, it isn't. Cellophane noodles shed a bit while cooking and add an unctuous quality to sauces. Asian long beans are not long green beans. If you order the green beans and think them a bit stringy, that's just the way they are. I like bamboo shoots. Some people believe it tastes like tree bark. 

To anyone who eats a gluten-free diet: They have wheat-free soy sauce and will prepare your whole dish with the condiment. Just ask.
author: Therese M.

description:
We stumbled upon this place because we found street parking nearby. Maybe we should have better guidelines for choosing restaurants, but what the hay.

The inside was pretty crowded. Not necessarily because it was bustling with people. No. It had a LARGE sushi-like bar dominating most of the space and tables crammed around it.

We chose to sit in the back of the restaurant, away from the door and bar where we might enjoy a constant temperature and quiet conversation. The server gave us a pot of tea and no water.

We ordered Orange Chicken, Mongolian Beef, and Henry's Special Chicken.  The portions were huge and served family style. The three of us were able to eat some of everything and still have over half to bring home.

The Orange Chicken was the best, but had a thick, syrupy sauce. Everything else was super salty. I could hardly get through the beef because of the salt. Not even the white rice balanced out the salt content. All of the meat was tender.

Our bill came to about $36, which I think was cheap for the amount of food we got.
author: Yvonne B.

description: Some of the worst Asian food I've had in the city. I got orange chicken and it tasted like and looked like they dumped orange marmalade onto it. There were goopy orange flavored marmalade all over it. It was disgusting. I have never been back.
author: David H.

description:
Pretty Tasty Hunan restaurant.  
Solid 3 or 4 star, but they don't deliver to Twin Peaks.

Seemed to be frequented by a lot of frequent diners.   

I got take out, and tried:
Hot and Sour Soup - wow was it sour... 
    Too much vinegar for my tastes.
    (My fav is Din Tai Fung in Bellevue)
Beef Pie - tasty, would def order again.
Henry Special - wow great ingredients!     
     Chicken, Shrimp, Scallops - another dish to repeat.
author: Fun T.

description:
This is the only place I order take out from now!!!

The food here is so fresh and so delicious! And the Service is always great whether you dine in or take out. And the staff is super friendly.

We like to get:
Seafood Soup- Its like an egg flower soup only better
Spicy Green Bean Chicken- I mean who doesn't like green beans & chicken (terrorist)
Mongolian Beef- Its the easiest thing, and its sooo good here! 
Shrimp Fried Rice- Made fresh every time so its awesome (nobody likes old rice)
Chow Mein - I've had the chicken, veggie, and shrimp. All delicious and not greasy

I had some other stuff too but theses are my favorite! and I love that they make things spicy! not American spicy but for real spicy.

So good!
author: Kameelah R.

description:
Yum.  The Diana's special is an absolute order - so good.
I also love, love, love the garlic chicken.

There is a reason that it's PACKED at noon so come early.
author: Tracie S.

description: Fast and easy to get into in the afternoon. Great food and outdoor tables!
author: Hollis N.

description:
From looking around at others' plates, I definitely wanted to try more dishes, but I was eating solo that day. Over-ordering is never an attractive trait....

So I got the chicken salad and it was huge and fresh-tasting and cold and crunchy. They could have lessened the peanut sauce dressing a tad, but still the taste was awesome.

And I also go the steamed dumplings with hot sauce (duh). They were also fresh and tasty, and hot and yummy. 

The place is clean and bright and next time I'm in SF, I'll go back for more dishes!
author: Valentina V.

description: A regular here for a few years now. The staff is friendly, the food is yummy and have never been disappointed. Recommend trying the curry vegetables and the Mongolian chicken!
author: N C.

description:
This place deserves 7 stars. 

First things first, the food is great and healthy with no msg. They are always so nice to me and my family when we come in. I have a baby and they are always so sweet to her. They even gave us cushions to make her comfy in her high chair. Truly, the nicest people. Can't beat their prices either. LOVE this place!

Try their Kung pao tofu- it's yummy.
author: Femme P.

description: Great service. Good people. The food is yummy, and it is family freindly. It a go-to plave for us.
author: Ericka S.

description:
Excellent Chinese food in the Noe. Light and airy, not the typical heavy, greased up Chinese food your used too..


Came on a Saturday night around 5:15. No wait. Nothing bad to say what so ever!!
author: Tiffany M.

description:
I am strictly gluten free, and I'm excited to say that this is a safe and delicious place to get gluten-free Chinese food! I had not eaten in a Chinese restaurant in nine years due to fear of contamination (regular soy sauce contains wheat gluten). In the past two weeks I've ordered take-out here three times and each time the food was GF and delicious. The staff know what you're talking about when you ask for your order to be made gluten free, which is comforting when there is a language difference between you and the people making your food. 

Aside from being GF, I think this is some tasty food -- and cheap! For one order I can feed myself dinner for three nights. Also, they are accommodating for substitutions (we've gotten tofu in dishes that were not listed as tofu dishes). 

Now the only problem I'm facing is how to stop myself from eating take-out from here every weeknight...
author: A. L.

description: This place is great, the quality of food is remarkable, the veggies used are always very fresh and they don't use MSG. Everyone working there is nice and friendly, the owner always has a smile on his face.
author: Negin S.

description:
This place is amazing, every time I go there to try a new dish I'm pleasantly impressed with what I get. 
Their dumplings are a must as a starter, especially since it is served with hot chili sauce to tack onto them!  
The service is memorable, one time I came in for a to-go order, and the order wasn't quite ready when I arrived.  Eddie saw that I was wearing a Sierra Nevada t-shirt, and hooked me up with a Pale Ale at the counter!  Makes it much more personable when your treated like a person not a table number!

To sum it up:
Consistent - You can expect a good meal before you get it.
Large Portions - You can easily eat half a meal/rice and have it for lunch the next day.  You will not leave hungry.
Inexpensive - Won't leave feeling cheated.
Service - Likeable service, Jeff & Eddie basically host the room, very cool.

Recommendations - If you've never had Dianna's Meat Pie, try it, very good.  Hot & Sour beef is my personal favorite dish, teases your taste buds!
author: Sean K.

description:
The portions are hearty, the waitstaff friendly, the space is clean, and the prices are un-san-franciscan ~ wait where am I? I should know by now never to underestimate a small neighborhood Chinese restaurant, especially one that proudly plasters the name of the owner on its sign. Henry Hunan Restaurant is definitely on my return list.

After a night full of wine and champagne for the New Years, I had a sudden and insatiable craving for Chinese food. I started off with hot and sour soup ~ which was a bit too thick for my tastes but definitely had a kick of sour. It had small flecks of dried red pepper which went well with the green onions and bamboo shoots. As sucker for mappo tofu, I decided to go with the bean curd with meat sauce lunch special for my main course. It pretty much hit the spot - spicy, thick, and flavorful. The sauce was almost like a chili and the bean curds were soft and not overcooked.

Wishing the location was a bit closer to the city, but if you happen to be in the area, definitely a solid option to check into.
author: Jasper S.

description:
Call me crazy but Henry's is the best! Great staff, super friendly and their food are ***mouth waters*** really gooooood! Okay, just by writing this review - I'm making myself hungry, lol! I personally love their dumplings, kung pao beef, and their different types of fried rice. ;))

***daydreaming starts***
author: Jackie A.

description:
I am super excited about this place. The food is really fresh and tastes great! 

I have a severe gluten allergy so I normally am too scared to eat at chinese restaurants because of all the soy sauce. The staff was knowledgeable about gluten allergies and were able to accommodate me. They have gluten free soy sauce and are able to make most dishes on the menu gluten free. I ate my meal and had no reaction. I will definitely be eating here again.
author: Christine S.

description:
3.5 stars.

Such a nice group of people who work there!  They made everyone feel welcome and invited.  Service with a smile!

We tried the Chicken Peking, Beef and Broccoli and the Noodles with Pork Meat Sauce.  We had a few TsingTao's too.

The Chicken Peking was the overall favorite!  A nicely sweetened sauce accompanied the chicken--it did not overpower it at all.  I'm going to have this dish again the next time I dine here.  The other two dishes were good--but both were a bit salty and/or oily.
author: Thomas D.

description:
We ordered from Henry's for the second time last night and decided to try some different dishes.  As before, everything was delicious.
We started with won ton soup which was just wonderful.
My partner ordered shrimp-fried rice, spicy hot rock cod filets and sauteed squid while I ordered beef chow mein..  All of the dishes were just great.
Because our order was so large, Henry's gave us a complimentary order of Diana's meat pies.  We got full before we got to the meat pies so we'll have them with the leftovers.
We continue to be delighted with Henry's dishes.
author: Philip C.

description:
This place is tasty and a particular bargain for lunch. The mapo tofu, chicken with string beans, hot and sour soup all were nice. We did have to ask for more spice, even though we ordered spicy.

I would love them more if they delivered to my place, but apparently 0.8 miles is too far.
author: Lauren G.

description: I got Henry's special and dumplings. The ingredients looked fresh but they were lack of flavors, especially sweet side.  I don't know if the real Chinese food is supposed to be more salty or bland than sweet.
author: EunJoo C.

description:
We dined here today from 4:20p -5:20p, so the service was fast.  I agree with David H.  This place must cater to non-Asian clientele.  So disappointed with this restaurant.  I've been to other Henry's and have not been disappointed.  

The Mu Si (sic) vegetable is 90% cabbage.  It was missing everything else: eggs, mushrooms, bean sprouts, onion, ginger, garlic, vinegar.  No flavor w/o the Hoisin sauce. The shrimp chow mein was good but again, cabbage is provided instead of a Chinese vegetable, and not much flavor.  Where was the soy sauce?  I shouldn't need to use it in a Hunan restaurant, and couldn't because it was nowhere to be found.  The won ton soup was good enough.  I suspect that the dishes in general have no flavor without the hot peppers.  There certainly was no natural spices.  If you want a "Henry's", go to the one in the Financial District.  Will not be dining at this location again.
author: crystal s.

description: Out of all the Henry's Hunan Restaurants, this is probably the best one - delicious food and solid service. We shared the green onion pancake, hot and sour soup, and garlic chicken. The pancake wasn't quite what I had in mine - much thinner than the pancakes that I'm used to. Hot and sour soup was solid, nothing incredibly amazing, but not bad either. The garlic chicken was great - chicken wasn't dry, but cooked perfectly. It's a stir fry with lots of carrots - get ready for that! The service was great too (for a Chinese restaurant, where the norm is that waiters are rude and will only speak with you twice.. when you order and when you need the bill). Overall, I'd definitely come here again... it's a very solid (somewhat Americanized) Chinese food place. If I lived in the neighborhood, this would definitely be a go-to Chinese food spot.
author: Cassy H.

description:
Tuesday night, we were on a Happy Donut high and determined to put a nail in the coffin of our food binge. So I found this place on Yelp. We arrived 45 minutes before closing time.

We were immediately greeted by a man who I think is the owner. I was pleasantly surprised by the decor - modern, high ceilings, pendulum lighting, a bit lofty. Unusual for a Chinese joint. 

Then I read their food philosophy, tucked in the back of the menu, which stated that they minimize the use of sodium, avoid MSG and are dedicated to making the healthiest, best tasting Chinese food possible. 

So we ordered...

Won ton soup: Simple and tasty. I loved that the broth was not overly salty, although I did add a bit of chili sauce for extra spice. And the won ton dumpings had generous portions of meat.

Prawn fried rice: Fluffy and not overfried like other places. I could actually taste the scrambled egg, green onions, prawns and carrots because they weren't inundated with salt or soy sauce. This proves that salt does not equal flavor. Salt just masks poor cooking. But the ingredients in this dish spoke for themselves. Score!

Orange glaze chicken w/ peppers: I liked that the chicken was moist and not deep fried. The orange flavor was good but I wished it has been marinated into the chicken better, rather than being poured on top. I'd try a different dish next time - this one was just OK.

During our visit, a handful of folks came in to pick up their take-out. The owner seemed to recognize them all. I notice when restaurants have alot of regulars because it indicates a consistent dining experience, not to mention good service. 

Overall I'd rate them 4 stars for service, 3 stars for food.
author: Mariela D.

description:
Clean, decent Americanized Chinesse food. Would drive here from another neighborhood but we were nearby and it fit the bill for tonight. Good for families. 

The eggplant salad was the best dish we ordered. You need to like garlic though. The hot and sour soup was really thick. Not my thing, but I heard Another patron rave about it, so to each their own. Tea was pretty flavorless. Prices were reasonable. Lots of room for strollers although it can get loud with the exposed kitchen. They have friendly staff, but seemed one hand short at 7pm on a Wednesday night
author: Jacqueline S.

description:
A happy accident.  We were driving around mid-day (around 3:45pm) looking for a place to grab quick and delicious food.  The restaurant we wanted to go was closed so we walked into Henry Hunan Restaurant.  We ordered the string beans with spicy black bean sauce and beef with bean curd.  The food was ok -- not too salty (yay!). The staff is very friendly.  Lunch special officially ends at 3pm but we asked if we could order from the lunch menu and they said yes. 

I would rate the food 3.0.  Extra star for the superb service!
author: Jister Y.

description:
I love it!! Great location with easy parking and I never have a problem if I bring my dog because of the convenient outside seating area.  Their Broccoli & Chicken is awesome and I never have a problem finding a vegan option for my more dietary concise friends and family.  Service is always great even when they're busy (they're busy alot) and the great people here always have a second to talk even when you know they're rushed.  

Could go on, but you should probably just try it yourself!
author: Josh M.

description: This is a good place for Gordon Ramsay to visit.  It's in a decent location.  The decoration and the lighting isn't bad.  But if you go there expect to wait wait wait wait.  Not that the restaurant is oozing with loads of people.  It's almost empty for that matter but you will still have to wait wait wait.  It took more than 10 minutes for them to come over and take our orders.  Then it took almost an hour after we ordered for the food to get to our table.  When the food arrived, it's slightly better than average oily Chinese food.  And it's super loud in here.  I don't understand how people can spend so much money opening up a restaurant/bar and not spend slightly more to put in some sound absorbing panels.
author: Byron L.

description: This is one of my favorite Chinese/Hunan restaurants in the city. It has a style of food that makes it different than any of the other restaurants and the menu options are mostly different. I highly recommend the Henry's special, the dumplings, and the bean curd. They definitely can make the food quite spicy but it definitely won't burn your tongue for hours. Also has a great atmosphere at a great location. And the staff are friendly!
author: Ben U.

description:
An unexpectedly un-American-Chinese restaurant. So says the Taiwanese girl! Nothing of the restaurant from its appearance indicates that it could be good: the name of the restaurant, the style of cuisine (Hunan = Chinese American, 99.9% of the time), location (Noe Vally, not Sunset/Richmond), lack of Chinese on the menu....and yet, it is actually good. 

My recommendations:
The "meat pie" appetizer which is actually scallion pancakes with shredded cabbage and pork in it. The harvest pork and Henry's shredded pork are both very unique & divine pork dishes. You will not find them elsewhere unless it's another authentic Hunan restaurant!

Not so recommended: smoked ham dishes. Alas, they were too salty for my taste.

General comment:

The food here has a homey quality (despite not being from Hunan myself). The service is friendly, ambiance is surprisingly...un-Chinese, and the price is ridiculously cheap considering it's in Noe Valley. Only set back may be...the style of the food here is heavily spiced, so it's always going to be a bit of the spicy & salty side. But except for the smoked ham, I found everything to be richly flavored and delicious. We have come here 3 times within 1 month and will for sure continue to visit this place.
author: Elizabeth T.

description: They had AMAZING hot and sour soup and I don't even like that kind normally!  Also decent orange chicken but a bit over cooked and chewy.  Sweet and sour is skip able!  Heard the table next to me raving about the meat pies!  Def a decent spot overall very nice service!
author: Lyndsi W.

description: Pretty good.  Really liked the "delicious meat pie" and the dumplings.  Hot and sour beef was pretty good.  There was a chicken thing that was ok.  Probably need to order a bit better.
author: Ben L.

description:
I liked it! The only thing I did not like was the fact that almost everything on the menu was spicy, even the items that did not have the chile pepper symbol next to them that was supposed to indicate if the dish was spicy or not. For example, we got the Mongolian Beef and it did not have this symbol but was spicier than the string beans we ordered which did have the symbol.

Other than that, it was great! Crowded, which is a good sign, but we were seated immediately and the last available table. My favorite was the pork dumplings appetizer, SO yummy and perfect! The waiter was also adorable and a crack up and made the experience really enjoyable.
author: Alexandra W.

description:
The owners here are extremely kind and the food is great to boot. I was running around all day getting items for my new apartment. After a long slog I wandered into the Noe Valley area with my last bag full of items (a rather overstuffed bag at that). I new 30th / 29th and Church had some restaurants, I was starved. I happened upon Henry's Hunan at 9:20pm. I asked how late they were open. The owner said 9:30pm. I laughed, apologized, said thanks, and turned to leave when the owner insisted that I sit and eat. After double checking to make sure he really meant it I kindly took him up on his offer.

The staff didn't rush me, urged me to slow down, and treated me with great respect, even though they were closing up shop and eating themselves at the end of their shift! I ordered "Henry's Special" - a chicken and prawn dish on the menu. It was great!

Henry's gave me great food and saved my day after a rather long one. I would recommend them in a heartbeat, hence my review here (my first ever to Yelp, and one that is truly worthy of being my first ever to this site!). I look forward to eating there again in the very near future :)
author: Art W.

description: Of all the Henry's Hunan locations, this is my favorite. So go to one of the others. I've been going to Henry's since the 80's and I still think it's the best Chinese food I've ever had. The harvest pork is incredible.
author: Adam N.

description:
My partner Devon and I LOVE Henry's Hunan. For a year and a half, we lived 1 block away and would eat here twice a week.  We love their staff because they are so friendly and welcoming.  Jeff, the owner/manager, always greets us with a smile and a handshake, and asks about life and what we're up to. And when we run into other staff members randomly in the street they always wave to us.  A+ for genuine friendliness.

The food here is fresh, flavorful, and non-greasy.  They pride themselves in never using MSG and always using the freshest ingredients; you can taste it in the quality of their food.  I always get the string beans and shrimp because they make the crunchiest string beans I've ever tasted - they're delicious! We also love their chicken with mixed vegetables, pork chow mein, rock cod fillets, sweet and sour soup, and wonton soup. Really, you can't go wrong.

Come here for the tasty food and stay for the great service.
author: Sylvia N.

description: Five stars for the hot and sour soup. Everything else is pretty standard, but I haven't found any other place that makes hot & sour soup as good as theirs.
author: Rebecca B.

description:
4.5 stars

I consider Henry Hunan Restaurant a good spot. This review however is based on take-out. When entering I was greeted and offered a beverage while I waited. I noticed the place isn't overally large, but just the right size. They had a good amount of customers who looked like they were enjoying their meal and the place was clean.

The menu offered: apps, salads,beef/chicken/seafood and pork entrees. They even have veggie dishes too.

The beef and broccoli isn't so bad.
The sweet and sour chicken was good and tangy.
The noddle dish with beef was good and flavorful. I just can't remember if this was the dish with the mild flavor because it tasted great.

I have tasted a few other things in the past and think this place is tasty from my experience and would recommend some people to try it out  for dining in or out.

Good service
author: Dani D.

description: Excellent Chinese and super fast delivery.  We love the Kung Pao shrimp, beef and broccoli, and all the chicken dishes.  The delivery is super fast and always hot!  I wish they had online ordering!
author: Anne E.

description:
Cute little Chinese restaurant tucked away in Noe Valley. I wouldn't say they are the most authentic of Chinese restaurants, but the food we had was alright.

1. Spicy & Hot Rock Cod Filet -- my favorite of what we ordered! Fish was very tender, and just the amount of spiciness. It's actually spicy...for those of you who are scared of hot, ask for mild??

2. Sautéed Eggplant -- Not everyone loves eggplant, but I think these were decently cooked. Maybe a little oily, but definitely full of flavor.

3. Dumplings Appetizer -- Usually Chinese restaurants can make a mean dumpling....but this I'd only give a 3/5.

BUTTTTTTT WE SAW MARK ZUCKERBERG and his wifey there!!!!!!! Everyone was trying not to look, but it was definitely kind of obvious that we all were stealing glances at Mr. Zuckerberg every other second. haha.
author: Liz W.

description:
They're so sweet here. 
But the Mu Si (Moo Shu) Pork (first time I've ordered it) was a big let down.
it's 90% cabbage/bamboo and 10% pork strips.
Eric's (down the street) is MUCH better. 

The tofu and bok choy was healthy and fresh, but almost flavorless. 
Maybe it was an off night?
author: Bonnie B.

description:
I've only done take out from this Henry's Hunan since I live closer to it. Coming in though, it's clean inside and its one of the nicer looking Henry's Hunan.

The food here is okay. Forgot what I've ordered before but recently I ordered the garlic chicken and the minced pork noodle with hunan sauce. They have one that doesn't use the hunan sauce so its not as spicy. The garlic chicken is good but it's lacking in something and a bit too much carrots to my liking. The noodles are good but I like it much better at the other Henry's Hunan on Natoma more. Maybe I'm just biased, but I think the Natoma one tastes more "authentic" (not that I know what authentic Hunan food tastes like) but the one here seems more catered to the patrons in Noe/Mission area.

Overall the food is decent,
author: Johnson S.

description: not the best chinese food. It wasn't horrible but it was definitely over priced for what its worth. the prawns fried rice was extremely boring and the prawns were more like frozen tiny shrimp. Hunans special was nothing special. it had frozen scallops and weird shaped shrimps. honestly tasted like a typical Chinese dish that was priced double the amount. Nevertheless, this place is 100% better then mission chinese food.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Decent prices... but a lot of dishes are far too greasy (chow mein, broccoli beef, sweet & sour chicken). 

Yes, sometimes I just want to eat a carton of greasy chow mein, but if all the dishes ordered are super-greasy, it really just leaves me regretting eating here to begin with. With that being said, the left-overs the following day were just barely ok and clearly lacking in substance.

Popular spot in Noe Valley. Expect a wait. The restaurant is some-what small.

DELICIOUS sweet & sour soup. 

Friendly owner and staff. Parking is hard to find. But hey, that's SF for ya. I suppose it's easier to find parking near the restaurant than if it were located on 24th with ALL the other restaurants and bars in the neighborhood.
author: Drea B.

description: This place is REALLY delicious. The service is warm. The ambiance is comfortable. The prices are right. This place has it all. I ordered the hot and sour soup, which is among the best I've ever had. And I had the Kung Pao Chicken, which was spicy and tasty. The balance was just right with peanuts, ginger, black bean saltiness, bell pepper, oil, flavorful chicken... perfect. Even the white rice was exceptional. And to top it off, lots of tasty tea in a beautiful and large pot. I'll be back.
author: Aaron W.

description:
I've tried a couple of delivery places for Chinese food since moving to the city and, by far, Henry's Hunan is the best. Ordered the garlic chicken and the beef with broccoli. First of all delivery took less than 30 minutes at prime dinner time and the food was piping hot (yay). The beef and broccoli was really delicious. The garlic chicken could use more garlic but don't take it too much to heart, I really really love me some garlic. Both dishes had fresh veggies cooked to perfection. For instance the broccoli was a vibrant green and retained it's shape, not the limp army green piece of what might be broccoli that you get other places. And not too expensive.

Short version: will definitely order again.
author: Andrea J.

description: Delicious affordable lunch menu, and this is one of the only chinese restaurants in the city I have attempted to eat at - because I am gluten-free so can't eat soy sauce. The staff at Henry's is familiar with this problem and keeps gluten-free soy sauce on hand and can make many of the dishes on the menu gluten free. I'm sure other folks with celiacs have been missing chinese food over the years, so Henry's is a great resource. I particularly like their Kung Pao Shrimp lunch.
author: JD M.

description:
If you're looking for a local chinese restaurant with superb, fresh food and immaculate service, then this is the place to go.  The owner treats all of his customers as if they were friends for years, so it's always good to socialize with someone that remembers your name and what's going on in your life.

As for the food, the minced pork noodle dish with cabbage and the "Hunan Secret Sauce" (which is basically homemade peanut sauce) is one of the best noodle dishes I've had in San Francisco.

This place is definitely a must if you live in Noe Valley and you're into a neighborhood restaurant with charm and good folk.  Check it out.
author: B J.

description:
Onion pancake, awesome, you should try, it was flaky and yummy, house bean curd, awesome, I thought the flavor was incredible, scallops, awesome, I suggest extra spicy, string bean shrimp, awesome, the string beans were so fresh they cracked when you bite into them, and the shrimp was cooked perfectly.  

The seafood was cooked amazingly, the scallops were perfect.  My aunt and mom liked it also.  I will definitely go back.  While I was there I remember that I said, "You can tell the cook cares about their food.  I want to go and kiss the chef.  You can taste the love!"

Our waiter was also really friendly.  5 stars.
author: Cynthia B.

description: this is a very nice neighborhood place; it was our first time there.  The appetizer dumplings are outstanding; wonton soup good; a special dish (can't remember the name :-) also very good.  We will definitely go back
author: Tom F.

description:
i turn 24 this year and i've been eating chinese food since i was 5. so let me tell you that henry's hunan is some pretty good chinese food. is it the best i've had? no.. but it's still deeeeeeeeelicious. i came here with a friend visiting from brooklyn and we absolutely decimated our order of hot and sour beef, kung pao tofu and smoked ham with string beans. 

SMOKED HAM EVERYONE!!! GET IT! its salty yet smoky flavor is amazing with everything that its put in. 

in conclusion, i love henry's!
author: Alyssa L.

description:
Shredded Pork, Braised rock cod, smoked ham chow mein and hot and sour chicken.

chow mein was very good;  hot and sour chicken was surprisingly good;  the shredded pork had a touch too much salt; and the braised rock cod was good
author: Bill L.

description: I love the food here. It's authentic. Everything has a good amount of vegetables. The smoked specialties are wonderful. I'm partial to the ma po tofu, chines style vegetables, and a few dishes that can be challenging to the uninitiated.The owner is sweet and checks on the guests. If you call for delivery, they are very honest when they cannot possibly bring you food on time. They have tamari and are very careful is you cannot eat gluten or wheat.
author: Therese M.

description: Super tasty smoked ham chow mein. Definitely a great and fast Chinese spot if you make peace with the amount of grease in the food.
author: Charles L.

description:
Dear Henry,

Ordered from you for the first at about 8PM last night (Friday) and you told me it would be ready in 20 minutes.  I showed up 25 minutes later, thinking that as it was Chinese it would surely be ready.  I was in the middle of watching Colorado play their first football game of the year, so I was anxious to make it a quick trip.  It was not.
