I got their and sat at your bar (no TV) waiting for 20 minutes.  

A few suggestions:

1) I'm fine if it's going to take 45 minutes, just tell me and I will show up 45 minutes after I order.  You're happy.  I'm happy.

2) If I do show up after twenty minutes and you know I will be standing there for twenty minutes, pour me a half beer or a half glass of wine on the house.  An impatient customer will suddenly love you and not mind the wait.  Believe me, it works.

3) Tell me how long it will be once I am there if you don't have the info when I call.  Don't just tell me every two minutes ten times in a row that it will be ready soon.  I live a block away.  I can come back in 20.  I'd rather be hurt by the truth than happy with a lie.

That said, your food was awesome and I liked seeing your cooks prepare the food on a sweet wok, home style.  Your food was fresh, not too fried; far superior to both Alice's and Eric's.  Despite the long wait I will come back, just 40 minutes after I order next time.  And If I show up 20 mins before the order is ready, hit me with a half beer, please.  I will love you.

Again, really good Chinese - best I've had in Noe.

Johny
author: Johny X.

description: It's not an over statement... Their food is amazing and their service is above and beyond... Their food is always so freshly made and can't complain of food portion... We always leaving with a happy full tummy!!! I had their onion cake for the very first time today, after more than 12 yrs of having Henry's and all I can say is "why did I wait this long!!!??" Love it!!!
author: Abby E.

description:
meat pie is A+

smoked ham special w/ black bean sauce + chilis is A+

softest, most un-crispy, ultra smooth and mushy sweet and sour pork i've ever had. the outside should be crispy and not soft like pudding, right? 

nothing special here folks. if there was, it's definately out and gone. at this point i think henry could care less based on what I ate yesterday, lol. 

still, if you keep second guessing yourself, just get the meat pie. that alone might be worth it for some people. everything else is at your own risk.

keep in mind the ratio of meat to crispy coating is about 10x's more coating than meat when ordering the well known sweet and sour pork dish.  also do not expect it to be crispy. and it could taste like yesterday.
author: Jack N.

description:
Appetizer: The dumplings (in hot sauce) are very tasty! 

Main dishes: Deep-fried pork strips - yummy! Has the Asian "wok hay" - the taste that comes with excellent stir frying in the wok. 

Spicy eggplants - not so good. Mediocre.

Service is wonderful. Super friendly and attentive to customers' needs. Really feel at home. 

All in all - not the best Chinese restaurant in town, but definitely better than average. The service alone makes it stand out. The food isn't too bad, either. Some are pretty yummy.
author: Rachel W.

description:
Jeff and Eddy come from a long line of service professionals. In fact, when I was in San Francisco for my 21st birthday, nearly 30 years ago, I ate at the old Henry's between North Beach and Chinatown (now demolished after the '89 quake) and Jeff told me he was probably in the kitchen washing dishes that day.

It's so nice to have Chinese food made by hand, sauces made from scratch, not a lot of sweetness (even the sweet n sour is well tempered!) and I can have it really hot & spicey or not at all. 

The Hunan dishes are, naturally, a stand out. Hunan Velvet Chicken, a brilliant option if you're *not* in the mood for spicey, is a lovely, well rounded dish with a delicate sauce that highlights the flavors of all the vegetables and the chicken. Henry's special, with its paella-like mixture of scallops, chicken, vegetables, spicey peppers (adjustable, to your order!) and sauce is a rich dip into an old Hunan tradition. Harvest Pork, my favorite dish on the menu, has a story behind it (read the menu!), fills the belly and delights the palate.

Henry's Hunan is a great stop for lunch, a wonderful locale for dinner and, if you plan ahead like we did, a great place for a celebratory lunch for 14.
author: Steven H.

description:
I just moved to the neighborhood and within a month this place had been recommended to me by 2 Noe Valley denizens as THE place for delivery food. Today, while lounging watching the NBA finals in bed, keeping away from the strange and miserable June weather, I was finally lazy enough to necessitate delivery service and decided some Chinese soup was just what I needed.

I followed my trusted Yelp reviewers recommendations and as usual they didn't let me down on the Hot and Sour Soup suggestion. The soup was by far the spiciest I have ever had and was truly soulful and delicious. I also ordered the dumpling appetizer and have to admit they were just OK....the raves had me expecting something amazing but they were just yummy potstickers.

I also tried the Chicken Salad, which was like a combination between Pad Thai and Chinese Chicken salad - kind of unusual for a Chinese restaurant but a light and refreshing treat.

Finally, I ordered the sauteed deluxe vegetables which no one on Yelp has mentioned yet. I ate kind of poorly this weekend and felt like I needed some vegetables in my life. WOW! They tasted like someone had thrown them on the habachi first and then sauteed them...a really nice, grilled flavor. I did ask for light oil over the phone and am sad to say that they vegetables were still incredibly saucy (which kinda kills the healthy angle I was going for) but nonetheless, incredibly delicious!
author: Serena Q.

description:
For the price, it's pretty hard to beat Henry's Hunan, there's a good selection of dishes, everything is made fresh to order and the bill at the end will leave you smiling.

We went in on a Monday night and the place was buzzing, it was 3/4 full and it felt lik each time a table left, a new table sat down. Add to that, a constant stream of take-out orders and the delivery guy constantly going in and out the door... trust me, the kitchen was hopping. We ordered five dishes (always over order so we have leftovers the next day) and all were served quickly and piping hot.

We had the Won Ton Soup (Big bowl, good dumplings), Hunan House Bean Curd (awesome), Dry Sauteed String Beans (good taste but needed more salt & spice), Kung Pao Chicken (very good but needed to be WAY more spicy) and Pork Chow Mein (awesome). What amazed me the most was the portion sizes, for the price, humongous. There was so much leftover, we had enough to feed three more people easily. I do not know if the same size of food is delivered when you order out but I will try that next time.

My one disappointment was that "medium spicy" was not spicy at all, I honestly thought that they forgot to put any spice in whatsoever, next time I will definitely order "hot" or "extra hot" to get some heat going in the dish.

All in all, we were extremely pleased to find and try Henry's Hunan, it's got large, quality portions and it tastes good (other than the spice factor) and it's all for a pretty good price (Five dishes + two drinks = $42.00). We will be back!
author: G C.

description:
The dumplings are good. Thats it.

I love Chinese food, and enjoy everything from cheap takeout to expensive dim sum.  This is the first place I ordered from that I didn't even end up finishing my meal. A few bites in I realized the veggies were soggy and flavorless, the chicken was bland, and the rice was dry. The dumplings were great, but I was extremely disappointed by the entrees.
author: Alex L.

description: One of the best Chinese restaurants I've had  in years. And I haven't even been there yet, just delivery.  My mouth actually watered preparing a plate.  Their food is clean and awesome.  Love the Kung Pao Chicken and Veggie Spring rolls.  I have yet to have something here that wasn't completely delicious.  Spicy food fans, try this place!
author: Stephanie N.

description: Friendly-service and clean, modern space.  The food was decently priced, averaging less than ten bucks per entree.  But maybe something was off in the kitchen? Otherwise, the thick, sticky consistency (think: a starchy rendition of Japanese natto) of the Hot & Sour and Henry's Special Combo stir-fry were too displeasing and odd for a return trip. Seriously.. anyone else notice that?
author: Diane N.

description:
Henry's Hunan is one of the best Chinese restaurants in the city.   The staff are super friendly and make you feel like an old friend when you arrive.  The interior is comfortable and contemporary.

The food is really the best around.   We ussually get the same thing since we know it'll be good.  But I guess we should try something else since I'm sure it too will be excellent.

Harvest Pork - wow, lot's of pork, cabbage, and more.  Wonderfully seasoned.

Orange Chicken - It really does taste like fresh oranges and even has chucks of orange peel.

Curry Noodles - Similar to Singapore Style Chow Fun, but with thicker chow mein noodles.  Just the right amount of curry spices to make it delicious.

I want to give them five stars, but have to hold back only because they don't refresh the water often enough and it seems to take awhile to get your check.   But otherwise Henry's Hunan is oh so good!
author: Ed J.

description:
*Carry Out Review*

Just to be clear this review is solely based on a carry out. It's impossible to take advice on this restaurant from me, if you plan on sitting inside. 
Ok, so here we go. 

The cashier woman is quite sweet and very helpful. My office ordered shrimp and chick chow mein, curry chick, hunan velvet chicken, sweet & sour chicken, Henry's special, dumplings, the beef cake app, beef n broccoli and an orange chicken. 
Over all an ok dinner. Either their timing or my timing was a bit off, as by the time I arrived back with the food it was room temp. Not the best when trying to eat chinese food. Am I right? It's either got to be hot or cold eaten out of the fridge while drunk preferably. 

The beef cake was greasy but good, the dumplings werent the most flavorful (more salt), and the curry chicken tasted like an instant paste. 
However, the chow meins were awesome. Definitely the best option we ordered. 

I could be convinced to try again but I'd need to sit down inside. Who knows when or if that opportunity will happen.
author: Spencer C.

description:
I came here last week for dinner on a whim since the Japanese restaurant down the street was closed (go figure, the day after Christmas).  I was in the mood for Asian and my friends and I were starrrrrrrrving.  So hungry that we could've seriously ate a whole cow.  

I was impressed by the menu and its "healthy" efforts.  Hmm...this time, I think some yelpers  steered me wrong and so did the menu.  Though, I was not too disappointed.  And as my rating at 2 stars stand, I have had better.  Maybe not healthier but I've had some Asian fusion meals that 

First of all be prepared to pay for the prices on this menu.  Don't get me wrong I don't mind paying a bit more for a healthier option.  Though I must say that the food was a bit too salty for my taste.  I honestly thought that this being a healthier option meant that they were steering clear of the bad stuff (read the last page of the menu). Maybe they did and they replaced it with a substitute.  Whatever it was, I ate it anyway as the brown rice mellowed the salty flavor.  

We ordered:
+eggplant (without meat sauce)
+string beans with shrimp
+mongolian beef

To go: (for the boyfriend)
+harvest pork
+hot & sour soup

Highly recommend the string bean dish, the eggplant dish I was not impressed at all--it was too salty, and the mongolian beef, ehh--wasn't your typical mongolian beef dish. Hmm....did I miss something here with the reviews?

My boyfriend did not finish the harvest pork and that's an indication that it was not all that great.  After a 10 hour shift I was certain he was hungry but he left 3/4 of the box full of harvest pork.  I had a taste of the hot & sour soup....it was ok--3 stars for that. Ugh....I was clearly disappointed.  Did I miss something when reading the previous 4+star reviews?  *sigh* not sure if I want to give this place another chance.
author: Mary-Anne C.

description:
My partner and I stopped here for dinner. It wasn't our first choice, but it SHOULD have been.

Firstly, the service, while slightly slower than we were used to, was excellent. The staff were all very friendly and full of advice on how to reheat leftovers.

The hot-and-sour soup was some of the best I've had. It required no additional seasoning or soy sauce. We were hooked the moment we had our first slurp.

I ordered sweet-and-sour pork and pork chow mien. Both were excellent. I devoured the leftover less than two hours later at home.

My partner had Curry Beef and steamed rice. The beef was well cooked and very flavorful.

The atmosphere was great at this location. We enjoyed sitting by the open window and the high ceilings make the small space feel so open. There was a small amount of noise, but I am personally a fan of a noisy kitchen. 

We will return again soon to try some new dishes, but the hot-and-sour soup will always be the first thing we order!
author: Michael E.

description:
My family wanted Chinese food before my daughter's Christmas concert again, so I gave in, since we were in a hurry, and Henry's is near her school. 

The service by our server Cyndy was excellent. She was very attentive and nice and made sure we were happy. 

I learned they do not have iced green tea. Ordered a Sierra Nevada instead, which goes surprisingly well with Chinese food. The food is very good. I had sweet & sour shrimp, which is not on the menu, and mu shu veggies.

Bonus: The guys sitting next to us actually commented that our kids were very well behaved. Our kids have their moments!
author: Randall C.

description:
This was the best Chinese food that i have eaten in a really long time anywhere in the world. We went there for the first time with a friend who suggested this place based on a recommendation from a his friend who lives close to this place. Though we live in SOMA we went all the way to Noe valley because this one was rater better. 
Everything we ordered tasted excellent. Hot and Sour Soup, Hot sauce, Dumplings, Kung Pao and Mongolian stir fry. The service was awesome, very friendly staff - In fact it was the grand son of founder who helped us. This is the most food i have eaten in over a year. I want to go back for more again. Will certainly go back next week and every week :). 
Parking is easy on a weekend and its a beautiful neighbourhood.
author: P A.

description:
Some places really deserve their good reputation and this is one of them. The people here are totally about sharing their wonderful food and pleasing their customers.The service shines with friendliness and at the same time runs with systematic efficiency. 

I've eaten here (mostly by delivery) since they opened at this location. I'm writing this review now because of the very pleasant experience I had a couple of weeks ago. I told them I was going to potluck and wanted to take their chicken salad. I've done this before, but previously ordered four orders. This time I only needed two orders. They told me they only had individual containers or very large ones, and that it might look odd in the large container. I told them just to give me two individual containers. 

Before I went to pick up, I decided to take a large container from my house and see if they would put it in there for me. When I got there, the young man at the counter immediately smiled, greeted me and reached for the container. I saw him take it to the woman cooking the food and instructing here to put the food in my container for me. It was clear they understood my situation and wanted to help out. I really appreciated this experience. Henry's Hunan is the best! 

The food is fantastic and fresh, every time.
author: Paul A.

description: This is a great little authentic Chinese restaurant! It's a small place and doesn't have a huge menu, but what there is is pretty delicious. The portions are big and the prices are much lower than some of the other Chinese restaurants in SF. I especially loved the orange chicken and the dry sautéed string beans.
author: Lauren O.

description: I live right near here and just went for the first time. It was such a fun, neighborhoody experience. I went with my parents and my boyfriend. We ordered a ton of dishes: meats, noodles, potstickers, veggie dishes. Everything was on point and the staff was casual and kind. It was sort of a little kid-heavy when we first got there. I think they do a lot of take out because it's usually not full. I like it a lot. Come here to get away from the hip and pretentious areas of the city.
author: Julia D.

description: We've eaten there before and really enjoyed it but recently had them asked them about providing appetizers for a social gathering.  They did an amazing job of providing us with what we had asked for.  They even added some extra food.   The Eggs Rolls, Dumplings, Sweet and Sour Chicken, and Shrimp and Broccoli were a BIG hit.  Only bad thing was that there weren't any leftovers!!!  Great job and Jeff was  awesome to work with and VERY accommodating.  Even that's not enough, they delivered everything exactly on time as scheduled.  Imagine that, GREAT customer service, don't see that often!!!  THANK YOU!!!!
author: Don S.

description:
Delicious and friendly! What else do you want? 
Especially love the Braised Rock Cod. So good.
author: M.E. T.

description:
Good food. I appreciate the flavor, but was disappointed that their online menu was not the same as what they had in the restaurant. What we did get was quite good. 

I tried to order the following, as this was on the menu on their web site.

SPICY SHRIMP WITH BEAN CURD
DRY-SAUTÉED STRING BEANS
CHICKEN WITH STRING BEANS HOT

The "FRESH SOYBEAN SAUTÉED WITH PICKLED VEGETABLES" was unavailable, but sounded *very* interesting. 

The shrimp and the chicken dishes were fabulous. The beans were interesting. I wish there was a fried rice to go along with it, but I guess that's not Hunan-style. I would have preferred a more interesting rice. 

I will definitely order delivery from here again. Very nice service.
author: Benjamin T.

description: Extremely solid and delicious hunan food made fresh. Cute modern atmosphere and excellent service. Totally worth your patronage. (Good hot tea too.)
author: Andrew K.

description:
love love love Jeff & Eddie's - its the best place to take your kids and the food is delicious! We have taken our son there since he was a baby and now (we and) he goes with his other 3 year old friends and they are always looked after so well, Jeff and his wife watch out for them and never mind if there is a bit of noisy behaviour!
food is great, service is wonderful and the welcome is always so warm!
author: Jo S.

description:
First time, and it won't be the last!

The service was friendly but slow due to insufficient staffing, perhaps because of the holidays? The small dining room was coooooold! No heat, the metal chairs didn't help with comfort, and we wore our coats the entire meal.

The hubby and I started off with wafer thin, delightfully crispy onion cakes, followed by a soup of savory wontons in a clear tasty broth. Our main dishes were Hunan shrimp and Kung Pao beef, and luckily we requested medium spicy, otherwise we would have spent the rest of the evening with our tongues under the cold water faucet. The flavors were amazing, and more so with the accompaniement of chicken fried rice that was light, fluffy and simply delicious! Needless to say, I left with happy taste buds and lots of leftovers to feast on for the next couple of days. At $45 (including  tax and tip) for all that food, the price was very right. 

The only things that prevented me from assigning 5 stars were the aforementioned slow service and room temperature which detracted from what would have been a sublime Chinese dining experience. I look forward to a future visit, and hopefully the environmental issues will have been resolved.
author: Daniel S.

description: Just gotta give them props again.  Went back and Jeff was there as usual and chipper and friendly.  Food was delicious and service was just right.  Found out I can ride my bike and avoid almost all the hills by going down Valencia until 29th and then cutting over so I will be there even more!
author: Gene X.

description:
Amazing food. This is my second time here and loved it both times. You have totry the hot n sour soup! and Moo shu pork!! the best I ever had.

This is not a coincidence that it has been Michelin recommended the last years (they have their posters as soon as you walk in)
author: Stephanie S.

description: Yum yum yum... ordered delivery from Henry Hunan and the food was very tasty and not greasy as some chinese food tends to be... will definitely order from here again. Ordered the dumplings, garlic chicken and beef fried rice. The only thing that sucks is that there was a min of $20 for delivery... but the food is so good and there is so much of it that I will enjoy eating it the rest of the week.
author: Diana C.

description: I hate their butt-murdering metal chairs but I love everything else about this unpretentious little place.  I especially like their smoked ham, which they make themselves.  Nice people, great prices and really good food.  Be sure to try the Smoked Ham with Vegetables.
author: Michael L.

description: Back to service problems and deciding to go take-out, if at all.  Not that crowded and loooooong wait for check.  The inconsistent service here is getting to me, if you can't tell!!
author: Susan V.

description: Henry's Hunan is some of the best Chinese food I've had in San Francisco, we were not disappointed. The customer service was awesome and the service was top notch, they were friendly and always attentive. What can I say, we'll be back soon!! We ordered Kung Pao Chicken, Fresh sautéed Squid and Dry-sautéed string beans... Everything arrived hot and on time, making our nice evening even better.
author: Navdeep J.

description: Soooooo good and GREAT customer service!!! We love it and we will be coming here for years to come. Jeff is the best.
author: Margaret W.

description:
Since discovering "the airplane hanger" on Sansome back in the 70s, Henry's Hunan has been top-of-the-pops as a premiere destination for fiery and spicy Hunan fare.  After a year or two being away from any of the Henry's establishments, we decided to try Henry's on Church Street.

Henry's son, Jeff, greeted us warmly and the restaurant was gleaming clean and modern.  Not many patrons and maybe it's because the dishes seem to lack the zip of the old days.  The steamed dumplings were not up to my memory (pasty), and the hot and sour beef was heavy (greasy) and didn't have the energy of days gone past.  Does my memory chip have Alzheimer's?  Nope, the back up files still say these dishes were without equal. 

I'll be giving Henry's another try.  The next time I go I'm going to ask about the annoying loud fan vent that hums constantly throughout the dinning experience.
author: K P.

description: Very nice people! ...but whoa, that was the saltiest meal I've had in years!! I need to go find a diuretic...
author: Venice Beach Dad K.

description: Love the food and the service!  I pretty much eat the same thing every time I go (cold noodles with chicken, lettuce and peanut sauce) but I also LOVE the dumplings.  I should try some other things on the menu since it all looks and smells fresh and delicious.
author: Elvis S.

description:
Great food, terrible service. Two tables that were seated after us left before we got a check. Never took our drink orders, and never got condiments. Bummer. 

Take out only from now on.
author: John O.

description:
Unquestionably, poor service and poorly prepared food:  I got lost in the shuffle of larger groups which appeared after I was seated... 

I never saw the waitress again after she took my order. I had to wave repeatedly at the bus boy to go find her.  Ultimately, she showed up  with the check and chided me for not complaining to her earlier about the hot and sour chicken when she saw how little of it was consumed.  The entrée was awash in vinegar - virtually intolerable and inedible.  

I never got any water.  The tea was sent back shortly after I was seated as it was barely warm.

The last straw:  having to go to the cash register to pay the bill when the waitress failed to return to claim my money after presenting me with the check.   I was sick and tired of waiting.  

More important:  I needed to get home to gargle and find something else to eat.

Five stars my aunt's fanny...no way, not even close.
author: William S.

description: definitely not traditional chinese food but it's not as greasy as others. and they use a lot cabbage, lot
author: Ss L.

description: We came here after Toast (next door) screwed up our reservations. We loved Henry's hunan - Fantastic food, very friendly service, wonderful overall experience
author: Paul M.

description: Stopped in to get some Hot and Sour Soup to tend to my horrible cold.  They were quick to get me my soup to go!  I have to say this was the best Hot and Sour Soup that I have had to date!  I am going to make sure that I go back and try other dishes.
author: Megan D.

description: They are SO nice here! Every time I go, they always remember what I order, and actually call me by name so it has a real neighborhood feel. The hot and sour soup is out of this world, as are the string beans. As a plus, if you are gluten free, they are totally accommodating. Not only did they roll out the gluten free products for my man, who is normally afraid to eat Chinese, but they remembered it when we went back weeks later. What service!
author: Jessica H.

description: For me, the measure of a good Chinese restaurant is their hot and sour soup. Henry's gets a B+ from me.  When my wife first ordered the cod dish I thought she made a mistake, the only mistake would be not trying it. Delicious! We have eaten there about ten times, every time has been great. The place is always busy for dinner rush, go a little early or else it may take a while. Even so, the wait would be worth it.
author: Jim H.

description:
Stopped by here for lunch the other day and enjoyed the attentive, friendly service and the very generously portioned plates (I took about half the food back to my apartment).

None of the various dishes I tried struck me as extraordinary but they all were good.  This goes for the hot and sour soup that comes with lunch specials, the cold seafood noodles and the bean curd with meat sauce (mapo tofu).  Spring rolls and dumplings were also fine.  I was struck how little spiciness any of the plates indicated with a red pepper on the menu actually had.

The space is airy and very pleasant.
author: Thor T.

description:
--Delivery Review--

I read over the reviews for this place and I really wanted to like the food.  I ordered the velvet chicken, the eight veggie deluxe, hot and sour soup, and the garlic shrimp.  The person who took my order was polite and answered my questions patiently, despite my being able to hear the chaos in the background.  

The food took over an hour to reach my place and that was all fine and good, but be prepared to wait more than their quote.  ( was quoted 50 min ) 

The food was a bit of a let down.  There was a lot of oil and a lot of similar veggies in the dishes making the them almost indistinguishable except for the proteins involved.  And there was just a sprinkle of shrimp and chicken.  The rice was cooked well, and I was happy to have the choice of brown rice over white.  

Overall the food was ok.  Nothing to write home about as far as delivery is concerned.
author: Sallie J.

description:
I popped in here randomly on Wednesday for lunch when I had nothing else to do and my boyfriend was trying to get away from me and I was just trying to find excuses to keep him with me just a little bit longer. It seems like all Chinese food is only so-so. There are so many fish in the sea that none really pop out and say "HEY! GUESS WHAT! THIS FOOD IS DELICIOUS AS HELL". Well, just when I had given up on most Chinese food, Henry's Hunan landed on my tongue and changed my mind.

It was simple, really. We walked in and were greeted with smiles and a restaurant filled with natural light. We sat down and were immediately served a steaming pot of tea and two bowls of hot & sour soup--which was perfectly balanced and delicious. We ordered our lunch specials, me the shrimp & broccoli and boyfriend the beef with vegetables. It came out quickly, along with the little salad my dish came with, and it was wolfed down even more quickly. The sauce wasn't too heavy and the spices were perfect. The shrimp were heavenly and there were plenty of them. Broccoli was bright and fresh. I also loved the dishware! Jesus I sound like such a nerd. The only thing was that I asked for brown rice but got white rice instead. That's okay, next time, Henry's. Because there certainly will be a next time!
author: Laura M.

description:
Henry Hunan Restaurant is better than average chinese take out. This is no secret - the wait time for take out last Saturday night was 2 hours! Normally the wait time is about 20 minutes.

Fried pork dumplings, kung pow chicken, beef with string beans, and chicken and broccoli never disappoint.

They deliver to Bernal Heights.
author: Claire B.

description:
Full disclosure: Nancy O. and Selin K. below are my friends, and what holds us together, mostly, is our love of these dang meat pies! Always order x2 what you think you need because once they come to the table, you will cut your best friend for one more bite. Eddie is AWESOME, super friendly, and fun. This is a great neighborhood joint, and while Eric's down the street gets a lot of business I much prefer Henry's. 

The hot and sour soup is also a must-have, as well as their green beans.
author: Christina C.

description: I NEVER write these things but OMG this place is delicious! I've moved here from Ohio and surprisingly the food there is so much more better than here. Until I found this place ! So much flavor first, every where else is so bland the meat is good and LOOKS like chicken taste like chicken so it must be chicken ha but seriously this place is the bomb dot com
author: K J.

description: Greasy Chinese. I'll keep looking for a better delivery spot.
author: anne r.

description:
We're big fans of this place -- the staff, the food, the "neighborhood place" atmosphere, the prices. 

My partner needs to restrict his salt intake, and they always accommodate us here - explaining which entrees are typically low-salt, and which can even be made salt-free. 

The food is flavorful and never greasy, 

Yum and yum.
author: Tom R.

description:
After seeing Selin's review, I had to comment.  Yes, the meat pies here are good... but I'm not so sure they're Chinese (sorry SeRin).  I've only tried a couple other things on the menu, since every time I go we fill up on meat pies (let me reiterate, they are pretty damn good.)

Extra stars for the excellent service!  I'll update sometime when I can bring myself to order a full meal that doesn't inlude a meat pie!
author: Nancy O.

description:
Excellent customer service.  I ordered take-out last night (including moo shu chicken).  It only included 4 "pancakes" which wasn't enough for me.  I went back there today and asked if I could buy more "pancakes" for my leftovers and they gave me 4 more free of charge.  You can't beat that.

Ordered the moo shu chicken + fried cod, both solid choices although the fish was a bit on the salty side.  Affordable, great location, and can't beat the service.
author: lil c.

description: Good food, ordered chicken chowmein and it was plentiful and tasted great, hot and sour soup was also well done. Good service and will come back.
author: Brad D.

description: That was damn good! Good pricing, really friendly service, decent ingredients, nice modern-ish, yet homey space, with yummy food. As for how Chinese the food was/is, well, no idea. My sweet n' sour chicken, however, was really good, and the noodle dish with cucumbers and whatever was so good and refreshing, I'm about to finish my leftovers. Oh, and look at that, I have good fortune coming from the cookie. Awesome.
author: Patrick W.

description:
I was lead astray by the other reviews!  My hot and sour soup had way too much corn starch.  We joked it would turn to jello once it cooled down.

We had kung pao chicken, chow mein, and the 8 delights veggie.  The food needed more flavor.  Sadly I think the missing extra kick in taste is MSG.  Cancer or yummy goodness?  Tough choice for a food lover!

Everyone at the restaurant is very very nice.  Great neighborhood spot.  Funny to get chinese food from such a nice clean restaurant.  My disappointment on the first try won't keep me from coming back.  I'll give it another go simply because of the customer service.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
We're lucky to have such an awesome place so close to home. Henry's is definitely part of our home's weekly menu. Take-out is delicious and quick on pick-up. Eating in is always a treat, since the staff is friendly and attentive. It's always a blast to see the kitchen in total chaos, but of the good kind.

If you're going to have anything you need to have the Chicken and String Beans. The chicken is cooked perfectly with the string beans having that delicious crunch. Always a favorite.
author: Steve R.

description:
Jeff and Eddie are the patron saints of Noe Valley toddlers.  We wandered in on a Saturday after a busy morning at the zoo, two cranky two-year-olds in tow.  They happily attended to us, bringing goodies right away to prevent melt-downs, not batting an eyelash at the flying food missiles.   When one of the wayward babies (mine) had a total, complete flameout, howling in hysterics, Jeff magically materialized with a bowl of fortune cookies, which resulted in an instantaneous mood shift from depths of despair to utter delight.

The lunch menu is concise, and while I wouldn't describe the food as super-fancy gourmet, the dishes are solid and portions are extremely generous.  Prices are incredibly reasonable.  Our meal for four adults and two kids (with leftovers to bring home) was about $30.  

Highly recommended for those seeking a casual, affordable and tasty-enough meal in a laid-back environment.  Great for take-out too.  This will be our go-to spot when Melty McMelterson is in tow.
author: Katy M.

description: Citrus and poultry should never be mixed.  Max has been saying as much for as long as I've known him. That's why I ordered the Mongolian Chicken, not the orange chicken.  You broke my heart, Henry.  Oh, and the food took 20 minutes longer on the carry-out than you said on the phone.  This has happened more than once.
author: Maayan O.

description: Hot sour soup. Delicious.  Brought right away. Green beans, spicy and hot. Do know that the onion pancakes and meat pie are both made with crispy fried bread. So probably don't need to order both. Meat pie well seasoned.
author: Summer D.

description:
we really had a great time and awesome food.
We started with Dumplings and ordered three different main dishes. All of them tasted great and it looks like we got hooked on Hunan style food.
author: Manfred H.

description:
I've been here 3 times and the 3rd time I decided on delivery.

I had their House Fried Rice which was very good! (It's also hard to get wrong)

I ordered their Kung Pao Chicken, which I was not impressed with. It was simply dosed with Chili Sauce and it had Black Beans! I've never had Black Beans in Kung Pao Chicken. I also noticed Chicken was sparse while there were a ton of vegetables....

They might be good with some entrees, but they are equally bad with others, so make sure to get the right thing
author: Eric A.

description:
I love this place so much, I had my birthday here last year. The food is great, its cute, bright, and clean inside (unlike the other Henry's I've been to) and Eddie is a gem! 

I'm not gonna lie, I go for the meat pies. I grew up going to a place in San Jose that had phenomenal meat pies, and until I discovered Hunan Henry's, no other meat pie compared. Now, thank god, I don't have to leave the city. Have you ever had a meat pie? Imagine something like a Chinese tortilla, flat dough fried to golden perfection. Topped with delicious minced pork, sprinkled with a little Parmesan for flavor. Then cover it with crunchy lettuce and top it with another fried dough thing. A-mazing. Before I eat mine, I like to jazz it up with the chili black bean sauce. And then I eat it like a sandwich. God, I love meat pies.
author: Selin K.

description:
ok- I was wrong. Since my unfortunate rice-spiked-oil meal here, I have had three delicious meals at Henry's Hunan. I was lured in by a big group dinner where I got to try lots of different dishes and most of them were very tasty and not too oily. I've also gotten the mo si chicken and sweet and sour prawns and they were fresh and flavorful. All of the appetizers I've had were very good, but possibly too filling, considering the ample portions.
Oh- and at least one of the guys who takes phone orders might be the single most helpful person in San Francisco.
author: Kely G.

description:
This was my first visit to Henry's in Noe Valley - I ordered Spicy Chicken & Green Beans lunch special, which came with a small salad and a cup of hot and sour soup. I have mixed feelings...

The downside:

- The "salad" was swimming in a pool of soupy peanut dressing. I'm not exaggerating about the pool. It was actually a cold peanut soup with lettuce and bean sprouts thrown in for texture. Not good.

- The actual soup was ALL sour and no heat. Even if it hadn't been for the overpowering vinegariness, I don't think I could have gotten past the viscous consistency. This wasn't your average dose of corn starch, it was more like runoff from a sinus infection. It moved like a jello. Not good.

The OK:

The main dish was fresh and tasty, but over-salted. Despite too much salt, the flavor profile was great. The green beans were well cooked, not too soggy, not too crunchy. Pleasant surprise after the sides.

The good:

- Excellent service
- Reasonable prices, large portions
- Good location with nice, clean interior

Overall:

I may go back and try something else. Hopefully they will have gotten their seasoning and proportions in check by then.
author: Prattle P.

description:
With the cold snap finally seeming to come to a close, I have Henry's to thank for getting me through it: I have been on an insatiable soup/noodle/curry/rice/salt-binge ever since the temperature dropped, and the lovely dudes at Henry's have been keeping me well-fed and satisfied with their delicate, delicious, and-- dare I say-- FRESH-tasting Hunan eats when I just can't bear to cook.  And you know what? I've even felt good after dining on Henry's!  This Chinese food makes you feel as though you are doing yourself a dietary favor!  Who knew!?!?!?

Crisp veggies, high-quality meats, delicate sauces, and honest-to-goodness culinary prowess are ACTUALLY coming out of this kitchen on a daily basis.  I have never really liked Chinese food all that much, but these guys have single-handedly made me reconsider Hunan-style chow.... and also, they are really, really nice people :)
author: Laura F.

description: Great selection of dishes, including the lunch specials -- delicious and generous portions.  The wait staff is friendly, and the owner is very nice and says hello to each table when he can.  My favorite -- the smoked ham & egg fried rice: it's not a dish found in a lot of other restaurants, and Henry's makes a tasty version!
author: Carlo A.

description:
On my fourth trip in the last month, I went to Henry's Hunan to try other dishes and eat in for the first time.  It was mid-afternoon and I expected it to not be busy so I could take my time over a bowl of hot soup and onion pancakes.  It was cold and rainy outside and this was the spot to be. 

I got the mo si soup and as Goldilocks would say:  It was just right. Tofu, a little meat, wood ears,  fresh greens in a nice broth with onion cakes.  I also ordered the eggplant dish to take home as well as the left over soup. I had the eggplant later than night and it was just the way I like it.  The eggplant was very fresh.  Again, it is meant to be eaten with lots of rice to carry the flavors.  I have enough for several days of healthy eating.

Plus, I got a chance to practice Mandarin in a comfortable setting with nice accomodating people.
author: B.J. W.

description:
I wish I can eat all of their food and not gain an ounce, I love this place, the best flavors.  I HIGHLY RECOMMEND THE FOLLOWING:
Diana's meat pie (its like a taco/tostada), hot &sour beef or chicken, garlic chicken, kung pao chicken, curry chicken, Henry's special (TO DIE FOR!), chicken with black bean sauce, chicken with string beans, spicy hot rock cod fillets, harvest pork, hunan spareribs, marty's special, egplant with meat sauce (TO DIE FOR!), country style vegetables & tofu (mild comfort food) and last but not least, NOODLES WITH MEAT SAUCE (TO DIE FOR!).  That folks pretty much covers 20+ years of partaking in delicious Henry's Hunan fooding (if there is such a word).
author: Sylvia E.

description:
THE BEST chinese in the city. Really. 
Jeff & Eddie are the kindest gentlemen. Always friendly, always accommodating, always delicious.
author: Lisa C.

description:
I wanted to like this place: the staff was friendly and the service pretty fast but unfortunately the food wasn't good. We ordered the meat pie, curried vegetables and shredded pork: everything tested the same, and it was so salty, I think I had my salt quota for the month (and believe me, I do like salt, just not a whole cup of it in one single plate).

I won't go back and am not even sure I'll eat the leftovers I took home.
author: The French ninjas P.

description:
Hot & Sour Soup is so ubiquitous, that many places do not pay it proper attention.  Henry's does.  They put the "hot" back in where it belongs.

The onion cake appetizer was also unlike any other I've had in years.  Light and fluffy, not heavy and dense.

The staff was all friendly and cheerful.  A nice secret spot on outer Church!
author: Ken B.

description:
Okay I will bump up the Noe Henry's to a long overdue four stars. My wife likes the food here well enough that I have been forced to learn the menu and I have discovered some things that I like: I like the tofu and shrimp, I like the string beans, the Hot and Sour soup is good.

Many of the dishes that other diners prefer I do not. I avoid the meat pie and onion cake as far too greasy for my taste. The smoked ham and Marty's special are far too salty for me. But other's rave about these dishes, everyone has their own taste.

Plus Jeff is about the nicest restaurant owner you could possibly ever want to meet. He is universally pleasant to me, even though he knows I wrote a moderately unflattering review before and I have to tip my hat to him for that. He is unfailingly polite and good with kids.

I have to admit, I am starting to become a regular here. It just took me a while to dig into the menu and find what I like.
author: Jim A.

description: Very cute place!  The ambience is great and the service is definitely one of the best for a Chinese restaurant.  Will definitely go again!
author: Mindy H.

description: Best Chinese with gluten Free!!!!  Try. Their hot and sour soup GF made with tapioca floor
author: Bruce B.

description: Absolutely fantastic food. From the outside, this place looks like a complete dive, and the inside doesn't help much...but once you get some of the hot-n-sour soup in you, you'll be hooked. Highly recommended.
author: Garrett M.

description:
Currently my favorite food. Really friendly owner and staff. Fresh, non-greasy or over-sauced meats, and crisp veggies. Flavorful but not over-salted. Reasonable prices! The meat pie on the appetizer menu is a must. The mini-spareribs are heavenly. 

I'm not giving five stars because I don't want them to become overconfident and raise the prices. 

Who are Jeff and Eddy?

Nearby Eric's,  Alice's, and Regent Thai are also very good, but this place is the new "it" spot on this part of Church St.
author: Lotion M.

description: Best Chinese food in San Francisco!!! No seriously.....no, like seriously!! Henry's grandson manages the Church St. branch and is doing a well job keeping in line with his grandfather's vision. Clean, flavor filled cuisine!! Now stop reading and go place your order...end of story!
author: Mizan G.

description: When no one works for you that speaks english well, delivery orders are destined to fail. Benton Ave is not equal to Duncan Ave. Now my food is cold. Easy fix, hire just one fluent English speaker and it will solve these problems
author: Ben J.

description: Henry's is a great place...it's very clean with an open kitchen, which I love.  They make great tofu dishes and noodles.  One of my fav low key Chinese places in San Francisco.  I highly recommend it if your looking for an easy place in your neighborhood!
author: Ben K.

description:
SO SO SO excited to have these guys open an outlet in the Noe area.  I eat at their SOMA location regularly for lunch (always interesting to see suits and web designers in the same place, enjoying the grub and doing deals!).  This Noe location is much more neighborhood-y, and the food is just as good AND delivers to my house (in the Mission).

The chicken salad is fantastic, and the ol' standard kung-pao chicken is solid.  Hot and sour soup is great, too.

I love the onion cake, but would only recommend ordering it if you're eating at the restaurant, not if you're ordering delivery/take away (you need to eat it fresh out of the fryer).

On top of it all, the staff is SUPER friendly and want you to enjoy their food.  They'll accept feedback openly.

A great, reasonably-priced neighborhood chinese joint.  Awesome.
author: peter a.

description: Yuck. After waiting an hour and a half for our food to be delivered it arrived cold. I took two bites and threw the rest away. Even after brushing multiple times I cannot get the taste of cigarettes and salt out of my mouth. Disgusting.
author: Al K.

description: I eat here ALL the time, because the food is fantastic and the prices too. The wok is cleaned after each dish is cooked, the vegetables are farmer's market caliber, the food so fresh. The family arrives each morning to work their butts off all day spoiling diners with the best customer service. I love my dishes hot, with their homemade hot oil added, but you can ask for mild. Chow mien dishes are made with long life noodles fresh from Chinatown, most dishes I have leftovers for my lunch. With the prices so good I can eat out often and have a second meal later. Jeff, his mother cooking and the rest of the staff make it feel like home. Get it to go. Hot and sour soup will cure any cold!
author: Paula F.

description: BEST. DELIVERY. IN. THE. CITY. TASTY TASTY TASTY. NO GROSS BITS. I will never call another Chinese food place ever. Have never let me down. If you are a super-picky eater (like my girlfriend - she even loves it), this is the place for you.
author: Zman S.

description:
Great food, good prices.

The Henry's Special, a mix of chicken and seafood, was excellent.  Both the chicken and seafood were cooked perfectly (seafood can get rubbery when even slightly over-cooked).  And damn it can get spicy if you want it!  For that matter, any dish can, just ask.

Service was fast and friendly.

Already a neighborhood favorite.
author: Mike I.

description:
So I have never actually been inside Henry's Hunan because I always order the food for delivery.  Therefore I have no comments about how cute or spacious or whatever the inside is like.  

However, I do have lots to say about their delivery service.  They are always very nice on the phone and always helpful with food recommendations or answers to my questions.  Delivery is always fairly prompt, of course this depends on the night that you are ordering (weekend deliveries take a bit longer).  The food is delicious, warm, fresh, and never tastes like it has been sitting around waiting to be driven to my home.  And, 9 times out of 10, the delivery person makes a comment about how lovely my home is...what more could you want from a delivery service?  

Now, to discuss the food.  Everything is good.  I don't like spicy things so I can't speak for those items.  But my all time, most favorite thing that I am craving now as I wait for the food to arrive is the CHICKEN SALAD.  I had no idea what I was going to get the first time I ordered it (it was actually a recommendation from the person who answered the phone at Henry's) and it seemed so simple...just chicken salad.  It is noodles+ veggies + chicken + wonderful sauce.  I can't even describe.  AND, the BEST part is that the leftovers taste just as good the next day at work.  I promise.  I would not lie about this chicken salad.
author: Mary M.

description:
Meat pie? YES

Onion pancake? YES

Dry-fried string beans? YES

Spicy-fried rock cod? YES

Free corkage? YES!!

This place is DELICIOUS and the staff is a bit busy and all over the place, but super nice. 

Loved my experience here. Yummmmmmm
author: Misha F.

description: My family discovered Henry's Hunan when it was on Bryant St. (not sure if they still have one at that location) over 20 years ago. I have NEVER had better Chinese food anywhere in the world and I have searched and searched. I now live elsewhere but when I'm in SF I make sure I go here. Absolutely amazing and Jeff and Eddie are like family :)
author: Preena B.

description:
I heart Henry's Hunan.  I use to patronize the Sansome and 2nd Street locations.  Now I'm glad there is one closer to my area.  

Upon arrival, I was allowed to sit anywhere.  The host/waiter took my order immediately but was soon forgotten.  During my time there, he was attending to the two women the whole time.  The cook/waitress bought me my order.  She asked if I got my soup which comes with my order.  She also got my tea.  Hmmm, the waitress made up for the waiters rudeness, so minus one point for him. 
  
My order, Diana's meat pie is my obsolute favorite.  The meat pie is sandwiched with tasty seasoned ground pork, parmesan cheese, and shredded iceberg lettuce.  The tortilla like crust is brown and flaky.  My pie was served with a bowl of hot and sour soup which was also tasty.  

The waitress was very attentive.  
The interior was clean and modern.  
There is parking during the day.

The good:  Attentive waitress

The bad:  The waiter who was distracted by another customer.
author: Nanette L.

description:
It's good here.  Had the: Onion Cake-hot and crunchy!  Spicy and Hot Rock Cod Filet-nice heat with just enough sauce to coat each piece of fish, deep fried but not greasy.  Prawn fried rice-good flavor and the prawns were fresh, large and cooked well.  Plus, the rice was cooked perfectly(very important in Asian cooking:)

Oh, and their hot sauce is roasted chili flakes in oil with salted black beans, yummy!

Staff is friendly.  Prices are fare for the 'hood.
author: michelle s.

description:
my friend wanted to go to toast eatery (i was craving their chili fries something awful), but since they were closing earlier for easter, we ended up here.  very cute restaurant with plush, green booths and bright red (haha, apparently, they don't look very red when lit) light fixtures to accent an otherwise plain interior.  plain isn't a bad thing, though; simple goes a long way.  not your typical chinese restaurant, that's for sure.

now, for the record, i don't really see the point in reviewing chinese restaurants.  i don't really know why.  i feel like it's just such a regular staple in my diet (lazy to cook, har har har), and i generally stick to one dish that i've been loyal to since i was in nappies.  i always get the walnut prawns, maybe some rice or some noodle dish, and call it a day.

not really something to run home about, is it?

but i got the sweet and sour chicken, and my friends got ... er, i forgot how it's listed in the menu, but there were string beans, and chicken with broccoli.  oh, and the meat pie.

1) meat pie:  o m g.  i could easily get fat on this.  i want their restaurant closer to me just so i could have this; it is incredibly yummy.  i could have this instead of tacos for the rest of my life, no joke.  in fact, who cares, their meat pie trumps stupid ol' tacos.

2) chicken with broccoli:  my mom always makes fun of me about how i'm more willing to eat vegetables when i'm out with friends, but i don't eat it when she makes it.  uh ... i don't want to insult the mothership, so i won't say anything about that but!  their broccoli was really good, and i kind of wanted more.

3) string beans:  had a little spice but not too bad.  even if it had a little more heat, i don't know if i would've been able to resist the temptation of a perfectly crunchy vegetable.  and string beans are just - whatever, there is no other vegetable.  your favorite vegetable is now irrelevant.

4) sweet and sour chicken:  just for this, i really, REALLY want them closer to home in the 'burbs.  SO good, i love it.  and fun fact - i don't like eating leftovers, particularly chinese leftovers, because it gives me the feeling of eating an abundance of grease and msg.  it's not a nice feeling.  but i kind of pigged out on this.  and!  it has pineapples!  PINEAPPLES.  ridiculous!  but oh-so-perfect.  i'm willing to bet that if you had this baby sitting in the refrigerator for a couple of days, it'd still taste like gold when you finally took it out.

anyway, yeah.  if i could kidnap an entire restaurant, i would.  (and they serve brown rice.  uh, yes, please.)  the service was friendly, and i had a really nice experience here.  i don't know what it'd be like if i came here on a busy day, but if the service is just as friendly, waiting for my food wouldn't be an issue (as it seems to be based on other reviews).  maybe i'm too early to be biased, but is it really too early to be anything?

whatever~ i'll be back! :)
author: Ashley F.

description:
I'm a huge fan of Henry's - been eating for years at their SOMA location, and I was pleasantly surprised when they opened a location on Church. The service is very friendly, and the chicken curry is probably the best I've had in the City. The onion cakes are great, as is Henry's Special (chicken and shrimp in a Hunan sauce).

I crave it, and it's definitely going to give Eric's a run for their money being a block away...I'd say it takes the crown as the best Chinese food in Noe Valley, and up there city-wide...
author: Brian M.

description:
Mmm...Henry's is my favorite chinese food i the city.  I have been to every location and while the decor is a bit different at each location the food is pretty consistent.  We live close to the Byrant street location which is good for lunch and now for DELIVERY.  However for dinner when we feel like dining in we will go the the newest location on Church.  All the ingredients are fresh and the spice level is always good.  Although I feel like things are a little less spicy at this location.  My absolute favorite things to order are:

-Kung Pao Chicken
-Hot n Sour Soup
-Meat Pie

Thanks for the yummu chinese Jeff and Eddie!
author: Ana V.

description: We drive all the way into the city from Walnut Creek to eat this food.  Our family has been eating at Henry's for 25 years(Sansome). Then Edward and Jeff moved out to Noe Valley so we eat at this location now.  This is not your typical Chinese food- you don't just order Moo Sho pork or beef/ broccoli(although they have those dishes) you need to order their authentic Hunan style dishes- Kung Pao anything, Marty's special, Hot and Sour chicken, onion cakes, meat pie- but be careful theses dishes can be spicy and delicious!
author: S S.

description: My coworker and I get this place for dinner sometimes by delivery, though it's a bit pricey - $25 minimum for delivery. Each dish is only about $7-8 though, which is reasonable, I think. I've always gotten the mapo tofu, and one time the tofu came out harder, but overall it's still good. It passes my mapo tofu test for Chinese restaurants, and makes me want to eat more afterwards! Service is hard to judge since we've only gotten delivery, but the last time we ordered, they tried to tell us that we were located too far for them...which is a lie. They came and delivered our food in the end anyways.
author: Melody L.

description:
I've eaten here and also ordered take-out. Great choice, especially if you are craving spicy Chinese on a rainy day. Thought it was awesome that they offered to make the Hot & Sour soup without chicken stock when we requested the veggie version. Other good items on the menu - veg spring rolls, 5-spice bean curd, veg chow mein, and eggplant with bean sauce. My sis liked the kung pao chicken (they added extra sauce on request). They do take the 'hunan' claim seriously - the food is *hot*, so be ready to finish off with some dessert to bring your tastebuds back to normal. 
Friendly, though slow service, while dining in; order was ready within 20 mins for take out.  Kid-friendly.
author: Shweta V.

description:
For the last year or two, nearby Alice's has been my go-to place for Chinese. 

Please don't tell Alice . . . but, I cheated on her last night . . . with Henry!   And he did me good! 

I'm not Chinese nor have I ever been to China but my guess is the food here is more authentic. Too often I find Chinese food laden with too much salt & too much sugar. Each dish can tend to taste like the next. That was not the case at Henry's. 

We started with the dumplings. Surprisingly, they were steamed, not fried. They were served in a small bowl sitting in a yummy, lightly spicy sauce. Very good. We also split the Velvet Chicken (they only use white meat here..YAY!) and Henry's Shredded Pork. Both were excellent. 

The space is a little cramped and the service a little inattentive but I am really glad to have a new much better than average Chinese place nearby!
author: Jeff P.

description:
Very fresh and tasty food at a very, very reasonable price in clean surroundings with polite attentive service. Like other customers we had a salty experience. Whilst the Eight Delight Vegetables (quite hot) and Orange Chicken (fresh and tangy) were delicious, the Kung Pao Shrimp was so overly salty the first time it came that we couldn't eat it and asked to send it back and we're not prone to doing that. But they happily replaced it, even though it was already replacement for a misheard Kung Pao Pork. I will definitely go again.

If you're not craving a huge amount of salt and chili spice ask them to tone down both on your order.

THEY DO NOT USE MSG; I have a very strong reaction to it and all was fine at this place.
author: Victoria B.

description: I went there for the first time last week. Their Kung Pao Tofu was practically a religious experience.
author: kelli t.

description: One of my favorites in San Francisco. I've tried every Henry's and this one's the best. The service is warm and friendly, the food is fresh and plentiful--you don't leave hungry. Meals begin with a small bowl of Hot and Sour Soup--delicious and just enough to stimulate your appetite. Their signature dumplings are a must for first-timers. The Hunan specialties are the best entrees--Hot and Sour Beef, Curry Chicken or any of the smoked specialty dishes are recommended. A nice, cozy place for lunch or dinner.
author: Deb M.

description:
I started eating at Henry's Hunan on Sansome in the early 1980's.  
In the late '90's I ate at Linda's Henry's Hunan on Sacto.
Since 2000, I ate at Jeff's incarnation of Henry's Hunan on Bryant.
Now Jeff has moved out to Church Street, and it's the nicest of the crop. Nice bright restaurant, and the best Henry's Hunan of the whole cartel.

How about all the name dropping?  I hope it gets me a free onion cake!
author: Brian S.

description: YUMMY is all I have to say for this place. Not just great bang for your buck but the customer service is excellent. We have always had a great experience and great food when coming here. ENJOY
author: Maria L.

description:
finally a chinese place that is free of MSG and full of flavor.

This place is pretty AMAZING.  The staff is really nice and food was awesome.  We got the chicken and green beans and curry noodles and it had the perfect amount of spice and the green beans were perfectly cooked.  The curry noodles were tasty and not oily or soggy like a lot of places.

We made our order to go so as we waited the server gave us tea and hot and sour soup as we waited.  That made the whole experience that much better.

We will return!
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Good quality Hunan American. Onion pancake was light and tasty, cold peanut noodles were delish and Henry's special with 4 kinds of seafood was very good.

Staff was friendly and quick.

My only complaint is that they definitely use MSG. They say they don't, but my reaction is very specific and it started 1 hour after leaving. Most people don't have a reaction (even when they think they do), and it does make food taste better so I understand why restaurants do it. I only get heart palpitations and a throbbing headache-nothing life threatening. No real harm, no foul.
author: Susan M.

description:
Oh my. The veggies are So Delicious here. Forget every gross greasy Chinese place around. If you want Chinese that won't leave you feeling disgusting, go.

The service was iffy--they took great care to arrange our plates and such, but took forever to notice we were ready to order. Takeout is probably the way to go.
author: Grant P.

description:
The pork noodles.  The onion cakes.  The potstickers.  The Marty's special.  The beef with mothereffing broccoli.
I would eat anything on the menu, this place is great.  Jeff is the nicest (and hardest working) guy in the world.  The Noe location gets more traffic than the Bryant St. location which is great but makes me sad because I don't get as much one on one time to chat with Jeff.
author: Natasha M.

description: I wish there was a place like this in San Jose. The staff is very friendly, but the service is screwed up :)
author: Nirmal S.

description:
Revised on 10/18/2012

Tried Henrys again and bumped it up 1 star.  This place is good for cheap, americanized chinese eats.  It is light years better than Eric's down the street.

A good place for a quick lunch.


--------------------------------------------------
Wow, this place is mediocre.  It seems to be doing well with the Old Man Fuddy Duddy palate of Noe Valley, but I cannot see why this place should garner positive reviews from people who have decent taste.

I grew up eating Hunan Style Cuisine every week and this place is neither authentic, nor comforting.  In my opinion, the quality of the food is below PF Changs and a step above the Panda Expresses of the world.

Positives are that its cheap, they give you alot of food, and good if you have kids -  but this isn't even good Honkified Chinese Food.  Henrys is just another ordinary addition to portfolio of average restaurants around here. 

Why do we need this place when we already have Alice's And Eric's?
author: Zk K.

description: Simply brilliant chinese food.  Fantastic service.  I heart them.  Eat their food.
author: Sarah N.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE!

I have some friends that live just down the street. We used to go to Eric's all the time but now we go to Henry's! They totally stole us!

The first time I came here was for my birthday. It was pretty packed for a Friday and the place is pretty small. But we didnt have to wait too long.  We were all starving when we arrived and it did take our food awhile to get to us...but they were really busy and there only seemed to be one server for some odd reason. But it also was their opening week. Once our food came we were delighted. We order the tofu in meat sauce, chicken with string beans and i forget the other dish but it was good! All had a little kick to it which was even better. I can say this and mean it...but it's BY FAR the best chinese food i've had in a long time. 

I've come here only one time after and that was to order to go...basically the same stuff and it was still good even for take out! My friends that live down the street go here frequently and have tried new things and from what they say everything is pretty good and the staff is very friendly. 

HENRY'S HUNAN COME TO THE PENINSULA PLEASE! But you are well worth the drive and looking for parking time :)
author: Jazmine S.

description:
So we place an order, one of us is vegetarian. We wanted one Beef Teriyaki and a Vegetable Fried Tempura. 
Once the order arrives, in a timely fashion, we sit down to eat and are surprised with the WRONG FOOD. .. It might have been a case of "lost in translation" we thought, so we call back to get our order fixed.
A nice asian-accented woman answers and I explain to her that my food order was incorrect. I received a seafood-sushi, instead of my expected deep-fried veggie tempura, and I received raw ...YES R A W ... beef sitting in a sauce that is cold. She immediately apologizes and takes my order once more, with some difficulty but we got through it. I asked if she could compensate this mistake with a couple of canned sodas (at ea/$1.50), she hesitantly accepted.
15 minutes later, she calls back (and I can hear an aggravated Asian male voice in the background), and she says "my delivery guy is saying he took order correctly, everything you said is in the bag, sorry but we cannot change order" and I replied "well if my order was correct I would be enjoying it and not wasting my time by making a useless complaint" ..and then she went off on a tangent about how the sodas were not part of the original order and that it was impossible to get my order replaced. 
Then, I explained to her that my Vegetarian wife opened her box of food, expecting DEEP FRIED VEGGIES and was surprised by SEAFOOD SUSHI. 
Yes, imagine a vegetarian taking a sushi roll she DID NOT want, but was too hungry at this point, and after two chews realized there was seafood in there...SEAFOOD!!!
I asked her to please take my order once more, that we DID want their service, and she refused. So I asked her to send me my money back, 30 minutes later a nice delivery man, apologetically gave me my money back.
author: Lookass V.

description:
I'm thrilled to find a Chinese place that actually serves good quality, delicious food, and not the usual cheap, greasy crap. Plus, it's close to the pad and not horribly expensive, and the people there were really nice.
I think delivery may be a bad idea in general. I went over and got it myself, so we were eating it 5 minutes after it came off the stove. Big difference.
author: Jonny A.

description:
Great variety of food.  First time at this location and did not leave disappointed.  Ordered the famous meat pie, which is a must every visit to Henry Hunan's.  Also had the egg plant and chicken with string beans.  Both were more than satisfying, just the right amount of spiciness as requested.  Service and cleanliness were on par.
"Woohoo! As good as it gets!"
author: Andrew Y.

description: I'm feeling very fortunate to live near Henry's.  The fried rice was some of the best I've ever had and the Kung Pao chicken was great and used very high quality cuts of meat as well.  On top of that, once the server realized that we were had just moved into the neighborhood, he brought over free(!) beer and wine for us.  I'm not used to that kind of customer service, especially not from my local Chinese restaurant.  The combo of great food and service did it for me.  Looking forward to eating here again soon.
author: Nate L.

description:
Good Hunan chinese at a decent price. A competitor to Eric's and Alice's both around the corner.

This is a second day of its operation review....the sauce was a bit salty. The workers are frantic as they seem very understaffed at the moment. Too bad there aren't any vegetarian appetizer options other than the usual fried egg-rolls.

They have an odd system of writing down orders which I would expect will have changed in a few weeks - a pink sheet with all the menu items listed. It says something about getting up to pay but just disregard it. 

Good for take out and free delivery (limited range, my guess, by a walking distance considering the low number of workers)
author: G J J.

description:
I swear to god, their Hot and Sour sauce has healing abilities.  Every time I am sick, I go there and get a giant tub and I am healed within days.  Jeff and Eddie are so nice and friendly, they are a welcome addition to the neighborhood.  Their pot stickers are addictive - ask for their hot sauce- and you are in heaven.  

Glad you guys have moved to the neighborhood!  My health thanks you and your hot and sour soup!
author: Carley A.

description:
Henry's Hunan is a couple of blocks away from where I'm staying here in the Noe Valley area of San Francisco.  

Small place.  Reasonable amount of seating.  Place was clean and friendly.  We got seated right away (7:00pm on a Friday evening).  

Tea was brought to the table right away - which I liked.  Started with an appetizer - spring rolls.  The came hot and crispy.  Not too greasy (which is usually one of my pet peeves with most spring rolls).  

I had the Mongol Beef.  My dinner companion had the Hunan Shrimp.  Both dishes were very good.  Not the best I've ever had, but quite respectable.  Beef was tender, tasty with a nice mix of onion and hot pepper.  Shrimp was done perfectly, tender, moist and flavorful.  

Service was quick and efficient.  Dinner for two cost us $31 with the tip.  

Bottom line - if you are in the area, this place is worth a try.  I'll probably be back again in the near future.
author: Andrea v.

description:
Cute little place around the corner from where we live - nice bar to sit at if you are on your own, and really good service.

The only issue I had with the food is it tasted too salty.  I ordered a noodle dish and a chicken dish.  The hot and sour soup is delicious - but could be a bit more spicy.

Since this is my neighborhood restaurant, I will definitely try it again.
author: Gina C.

description:
See My Review of Henry's in the Financial District.

The Gist:
+1 Star for Really Good Surroundings
+2 for Ok, but not horrible food.
author: Alex M.

description: I really wanted to love this place since I live around the corner.  TONS of salt!  The famous meat pie was "mysterious" and greasy.  I have had some luck with veggie dishes. Go tofu!
author: Amy H.

description:
Wow, I don't know why I should be so surprised at this restaurant, but I am. 

My friends and I go to Toast just opposite this restaurant all the time and decided to try this place.

We ordered two noodle dishes, one tofu, one chicken and one pork and it was all extremely tasty. Not to mention that after getting five excellent dishes and some drinks the price tag was still under $50.

The place is clean and has good lighting. The servers have some awesome smiles.

Also, I accidentally went in the back to where there kitchen was when I had meant to go to the bathroom and met the chef in the back. An older grandfather looking guy with an awesome smile and looks like he can kung fu the dough with the best of them.

Anyone, everyone, please frequent this place. You won't be sorry.
author: Mark H.

description:
Bomb.com for sure. 

Someone (my BF) said spicy and I said Yes Please!  We started off with the potstickers.  Get the potstickers.  They were unlike any I had before.  The dough encasing the pork was extra doughy and just plain delicious.  We then went on to chow mein and kung pow chicken.  The spice was perfect and the doughiness of the chow mein noodles was just as delicious as the potstickers.  If you can not tell by now, I love doughiness.    

The waiters were extremely nice as well as the decor inside.  Take a look at the pictures near the front, there are some funny baby ones.
author: Brittney B.

description: This review is for the restaurant as a whole. I'll be honest, I really like a lot of their food. Not amazing, but definitely solid. However, order it TAKE OUT or DELIVERY. We were in there last night (Friday), and waited an absurd amount of time - it had to be at least an hour - for two dinner plates. We could have eaten two meals at another restaurant before half our food even arrived, the rest came 10 minutes later. They were clearly giving the delivery and take out orders precedence in the kitchen, and admitted to doing so when we expressed our displeasure. The people working there were clearly overwhelmed, and the service was nonexistent.
author: Steve P.

description: Been there many times,Food always very good.THanks Jeff
author: Jim P.

description:
I live in Noe Valley. I like it. I try to support business in the neighborhood. Tonight I call Henry's Hunan (or Joe and Eddie's or whatever the eff it's called) to place an order for delivery after reading on multiple websites that they do deliver. Nope, sorry, they tell me they are too busy. You either deliver or you don't, not "we deliver when we have time". 
We'll see if I ever stop in to check it out in person, that kind of crap really pisses me off.
author: Ellen T.

description:
"Everything's coming up Milhouse."

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t7z192I-mQM

It's Milhouse's classic line from The Simpsons. Means everything is going well. And ever since booking the trip of my dreams to the magical white isle, life feels like "Everything's coming up Ibiza". Latest evidence, my fortune cookie from Henry's Hunan:

"Pleasures await you by the seashore".

I certainly hope so. This has been a long time coming. And basically since everything Ibiza related these days is making me smile, Henry's was pretty much gonna get a favorable review unless they seriously messed things up. Which they didn't.

Shrimp was steamed as requested, veggies were covered in a lovely black bean sauce, all the rice on the side was no doubt appreciated by someone in need down the corner, and my heart appreciated the no extra salt option clearly called out on the menu.

Everything was indeed coming up Milhouse, especially if he's on his way to Ibiza.
author: Jason B.

description: Went there for the first time at this location on Saturday. Food was as good as the other Henry's, This site is smaller than the other locations, but I think perfect for the neighborhood it's located in. Ordered the meat pie, beef and string beans, also the veggie chow mien and the orange chicken, and steamed rice.Everything arrived fast and hot. Now this is a Hunan place so asking for something not spicy is subject to every ones tastes. I and the other 3 people I was with thought the heat level was perfect. If you like hot spicy Chinese food for a good price and close to home, this is your place...Check it out...
author: Michael M.

description:
This is the best place.Ever. Not only is the food fresh, fast and delicious, the staff is incredible. 

We recently moved into the neighborhood and called for delivery during our move-in. The staff on the phone was incredibly polite and described various dishes as we didn't have a menu in front of us. When they came to deliver, they were like chipper-skippers. 

Fast forward a week and we ordered again (the same thing). This time, my boyfriend blanked and forgot that he didn't have any cash. So instead of the delivery guy (he's so nice!) getting mad, he just took down the cc information and chatted with us about the neighborhood and remembered us from the first order. 

But seriously, the food. We get chicken and brocolli, chicken chow mein and spring rolls -- spicy if the boyfriend is up for it. It's not greasy and packed full of flavors. 

This made me hungry, I will probably order tonight.
author: Sara W.

description:
I LOVE Henry's! I'd been going to their downtown location for years and found the food to be consistently tasty. When they opened up a Noe location, I was really happy 'cause I happened to live a block away at the time and it's always good to have a solid Chinese food place just around the block. 

My experience with the Noe location has been as good, if not better, than the downtown location. The food is consistently good but the decor is a huge step up from the downtown location (which is a bit of a whole in the wall). I agree with some of the other reviews that the food can be on the salty side, often, which is why I gave them a 4 instead of a 5 star rating. If you have any intolerance to salt, you should be careful about what you order. That said, they have a good variety on their menu and it seems reasonably priced. 

Some of the wait staff is shared with the downtown location and it's always nice because they always recognize me when I walk in. The service is good. I find that the wait staff is courteous and efficient.

Get the Harvest Pork!
author: Amit T.

description: I love this restaurant !!!!!! Always Fresh and Delicious. If you love Hot food get something with black bean sauce. I'm disabled and they always deliver my food with a smile. Thank you
author: Love L.

description:
The GO-TO place for fresh, yummy, totally delicious food.

As a long-time Noe Valley person this was my ONLY Chinese restaurant.  As a DogPatch resident ... it is STILL my only Chinese restaurant.  Have been going for years and have had only really great meals and experiences.  

I'm rather whimpy when it comes to spicy.  Jeff makes sure that I get just the right amount of spice without it being so hot I cry and not so light that it is uninteresting.  This is one guy who really cares about his customers ... and it shows.  

This is such an easy place to be.  The first time I went there I was hanging out waiting for my order.     I was included in the conversations and made to feel like a "regular" even though I'd never been there before.   I really felt comfortable.

I always order one meal for there and one meal to go.  Having two great meals is always better than just one.
author: Blanche W.

description: I was pleasantly surprised with this restaurant. Noe Valley is a charming neighborhood with lots of cool restaurants. Henry's Hunan has great service, and solid dishes with ample portions. I got a standard dish here: Kung Pau Chicken, and it was excellent. I find that kung pau chicken is a nice metric to compare different chinese restaurants. Henry's Hunan is a great restaurant.
author: Sirj G.

description:
Not bad but not good.  The food was fairly bland, not a lot of flavor.  The hot and sour soup was more sour than anything else.  I had some chow mein which was ok, and the sauteed eggplant, which was also just ok.

I give the food 2 stars, as I don't think I'll be going back.  I gave an extra star because the service was excellent and very friendly.
author: Cyrus C.

description: Love "Jeff and Eddie's" Henry's Hunan out at the far reaches of Church St. (although Eddy has since opened his own place out in the Excelsior).   Jeff and his wife are the kindest restaurant proprietors you'll ever meet and make you feel at home from the minute you walk in.
